PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
This humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth:

PARA.TAB: (1) They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
(2) They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a)The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b)The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space;
(c)The large star depicting a State and the Territories of the Commonwealth.
(3) They know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
(4) They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
(5) They are certain that any change to its form or to its acceptance as the sole Australian National Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should ensure that the existing Australian National Flag remains sacrosanct from change and remains the sole national flag.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

SPEECH.PARA: INTERNATIONAL WAR CRIMES TRIBUNAL BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this bill is to enable Australia to comply with binding international obligations which were imposed by the United Nations Security Council on 25 May 1993, when it adopted resolution 827. That resolution established the International Tribunal for the Prosecution of Persons Responsible for Serious Violations of International Humanitarian Law Committed in the Territory of the Former Yugoslavia since 1991, and adopted the Statute of the International Tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision to establish the Tribunal as an enforcement measure under Chapter VII of the United Nations Charter created, from 25 May 1993, an immediately binding obligation on UN Member States, including Australia, to take whatever action is necessary to implement the Security Council's decision and to meet the obligations imposed under the Statute of the International Tribunal. It is obviously desirable that Australia should be in a position to comply with requests for co-operation with the Tribunal as soon as they are received, and it is therefore important to have the legislation enacted as soon as possible.

The Statute imposes obligations on Member States `to co-operate with the International Tribunal in the investigation and prosecution' of accused persons and to comply `with any request for assistance or an order issued by a Trial Chamber'. Such requests may involve, among other things, the identification and location of persons, the taking of testimony and the production of evidence, the service of documents, the arrest and detention of persons, and the surrender of accused persons to the Tribunal.

The bill contains provisions enabling Australia to comply with these international obligations. It specifically provides for the handing over of accused persons to the Tribunal for trial; other forms of assistance to enable co-operation with the Tribunal in the investigation and prosecution of alleged offenders; the recovery and return of property and proceeds of crimes located within Australia; and the Tribunal to sit in Australia if it so desires. The aim was to keep the legislation as simple as possible, while still enabling us to meet our international obligations. The bill adopts a minimalist approach, providing only for the mandatory obligations imposed by the Statute.

It was originally intended that the bill would also provide for imprisonment in Australia of persons convicted by the Tribunal. We have been consulting with the States and Territories on this issue, as any persons will need to be imprisoned in State and Territory prisons. The matter has not been included in this bill because not all States and Territories have responded on this issue, and imprisonment within Australia is not a mandatory obligation under the Statute. However, I recognise that it may be desirable to amend the legislation at an appropriate time, for example, when all the States and Territories have responded, and if the Tribunal commences proceedings against Australian citizens.
I now mention some important features of the bill.

PARA.TAB: Part 3 of the bill covers the surrender aspect of our obligations. The Statute requires countries to `comply without undue delay with any request for assistance or an order issued by a Trial Chamber, including . . . the surrender or the transfer of the accused to the International Tribunal'.

SPEECH.PARA: Although the Extradition Act 1988 was used as a general model for Part 3 of the bill, the bill departs from that Act in a number of ways because of the different circumstances and purposes of the legislation. In this case, Australia has binding international obligations to comply with requests for assistance by the Tribunal, and as a result the mechanism for handing over of persons to the Tribunal is more streamlined and has less grounds of refusal than under the Extradition Act. The reason for this different approach stems from the unique nature of our international obligations.

One way in which this case differs from usual extradition situations is that the obligation to transfer accused persons to the Tribunal is derived not from a treaty-based obligation but from the duty of UN Member States to implement the decisions of the Security Council.

In addition, persons would be surrendered to an international body, rather than to another country. In any event, persons surrendered to the Tribunal will have the benefit of internationally recognised procedural and legal safeguards.

Furthermore, the bill provides for the Attorney-General to have a residual discretion to refuse the surrender of a person in exceptional circumstances. Although exercise of this discretion may cause some embarrassment internationally, it does provide discretionary protection for Australian residents that may not be available under the Tribunal's safeguards.

PARA.TAB: Parts 4 and 6 of the bill provide for other types of assistance to enable Australia to co-operate with the Tribunal in the investigation and prosecution of alleged offenders, as required by the Statute.

SPEECH.PARA: Part 4 covers the taking of testimony and the production of evidence, the service of documents, search and seizure assistance, and assistance in relation to the giving of evidence at hearings, and assisting in investigations, in foreign countries.

It also appears that the Tribunal may make forfeiture or confiscation orders under the Statute and then seek to have those orders enforced in Australia. However, it will not be totally clear until the Tribunal develops its own rules of evidence and procedure exactly what kinds of orders, if any, the Tribunal may make in relation to the proceeds of crime. It is only envisaged at this stage that the Tribunal is likely to make forfeiture orders and therefore the bill, in Part 6, includes provisions whereby such orders may be enforced in Australia. If the Tribunal determines at a later date that it will make restraining orders or pecuniary penalty orders which it might seek to have enforced in a particular country, or that it will issue information gathering orders, then it will be necessary at that time to amend the legislation.

Parts 4 and 6 are based upon corresponding provisions in the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987. However, one major difference is the grounds on which a request may be refused. While the Mutual Assistance Act contains a number of such grounds, the bill has only very limited grounds, namely that complying with the request would prejudice Australia's sovereignty, security or national interest, or that there are exceptional circumstances justifying the non-compliance. This is a direct result of the binding international obligations in this situation. Apart from this matter, the procedures in Parts 4 and 6 of the bill are almost identical to those employed in similar situations under the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act.

Part 5 of the bill covers the possibility of the Tribunal sitting in Australia. Although this is considered to be a remote possibility, the provisions are necessary because the Security Council Resolution provides that while the Tribunal is to have its seat at the Hague, it may sit elsewhere when it considers it necessary for the efficient exercise of its functions.

While sitting in Australia, the Tribunal would be exercising the judicial power of the international community, not the judicial power of the Commonwealth. However, Commonwealth legislation is required to authorise the Tribunal to exercise coercive powers within Australia (such as to compel attendance, and to require production of evidence). The Security Council resolution does not compel Australia to automatically authorise the exercise of such powers. As a matter of comity, countries would expect agreements to be reached about the exercise of power in their territory by a foreign tribunal.

Part 5 of the bill therefore enables the Tribunal to sit in Australia for the purpose of performing its functions, and provides that the Tribunal's powers while sitting in Australia will be such powers as are prescribed by regulations. Those regulations will implement agreements between the Commonwealth and the Tribunal about the powers that the Tribunal may exercise while sitting in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The bill is expected to have little impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue in the short term. However, there are possible implications for Commonwealth agencies which may be affected by the legislation. For example, there may be resource implications for the Australian Federal Police, and cost and resource implications might arise if the Tribunal decides to sit in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: These costs cannot be quantified at all at this stage, as they will depend upon the extent to which the legislation is used in Australia. However, the legislation will be reviewed after it has been in place for a period of 12 months to determine the extent to which it has been utilised and to assess the resource implications.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
INTERNATIONAL WAR CRIMES TRIBUNAL (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: This bill is consequential upon the International War Crimes Tribunal Bill 1994. It makes consequential amendments to certain Commonwealth Acts.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act is to the effect that decisions under the International War Crimes Tribunal Act 1994 will not be subject to review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. The reason for this amendment is that Australia has binding international obligations, imposed by the United Nations Security Council, to quickly and effectively comply with requests for assistance by the International Tribunal, as I explained in my second reading speech on the International War Crimes Tribunal Bill 1994.

The purpose of the amendments to the Director of Public Prosecutions Act is to enable the Director of Public Prosecutions to appear in proceedings, and to grant indemnities to persons who are to give evidence for the purpose of proceedings, under the International War Crimes Tribunal Act.

The amendments to the Migration Act simply facilitate the entry into Australia and subsequent departure of persons who are required in Australia for purposes connected with the International War Crimes Tribunal Act.

The amendments to the Proceeds of Crime Act enable forfeiture orders made by the International Tribunal and registered under the International War Crimes Tribunal Act to be enforced as if they were forfeiture orders made under the Proceeds of Crime Act at the time of registration. This is consistent with the approach by which foreign forfeiture orders registered in a court in Australia under the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act are dealt with.

The effect of the amendment to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act is to ensure that lawfully intercepted information can be used in proceedings under Division 1 of Part 4 of the International War Crimes Tribunal Act. Those proceedings cover the taking of evidence, or production of documents or other articles in Australia for the purposes of, and at the request of, the Tribunal.
The bill is expected to have little impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

This bill proposes to amend the Telecommunications Act 1991 to ensure regional, rural and remote Australians have access to telecommunications of a standard available to the majority of the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: A simple enough aim, yet one ignored in the current legislation.

If a telephone is considered an essential service in metropolitan communities it must be judged indispensable in rural and remote communities. However, gross inequities lie in the provision of telecommunication services between urban and rural centres.

No formal mechanism exists to ensure telecommunications in rural areas keep pace with services accessible in metropolitan regions. In fact, there is a very real fear that service levels will deteriorate in rural Australia as a direct result of competition.

The Federal Government must be made to honour its responsibility to provide equitable access to information services. Communications are the technological `highways' to future development in rural and remote regions.

Rural communities will face new threats to their viability if they cannot keep pace with businesses in the national and global economy. Rural Australian communities lacking digital switching equipment or that otherwise cannot reliably transmit facsimile, computer and other data, face a stunted future.

This is the gloomy prospect facing many rural communities given the government's vague determination of the obligation under the Telecommunications Act 1991 to provide a standard telephone service to all people in Australia on an equitable basis.

The Telecommunications Act 1991 (section 288) embodies the principle that all Australians are entitled to have reasonable access to a standard telephone service and to pay phones. This principle is know as the universal service obligation (USO). In its recent report on Mail, Courier and Parcel Services the Industry Commission defines a USO as an obligation which arises when a government requires a public enterprise to carry out activities which it would not elect to do on a commercial basis, or which it would only do commercially at higher prices.

The Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation, or as it is better known, Telecom, as the universal service carrier, is responsible for discharging the USO. While the alternative telecommunications carrier, Optus, does not carry any formal USO of its own, it is required to reimburse Telecom for a portion of the USOs performed by AOTC.

The obligation to provide a standard telephone service fails at the point of definition. In the Act (section 5), the standard telephone service is defined as a public switched telephone service, in other words, a basic service.

However, the basic service provided in urban areas far exceeds the basic service provided in rural and remote areas. Furthermore, the USO makes no provision for enhancing telecommunication services to rural and remote areas when access to improved technology becomes generally available in metropolitan areas.

The bush, once again, faces the prospect of lagging some 80 years behind in the telecommunications race, as was the case when the last manual exchange was phased out at Wanaaring, in western New South Wales, in 1991. While the basic telephone has reached 95% of all Australian households, service quality in urban areas surpasses that realised in rural areas.

Analogue systems are still in operation throughout rural areas which, in effect, deny reliable transmission of facsimile, computer and other data. A significant number of Digital Radio Concentrator Systems, the predominant rural telecommunications medium, suffer a high incidence of capacity related technical reduction in quality of service including, lack of service, dropping-out and noisy lines.

Such difficulties prohibit the reliable transmission of computer data. Furthermore, computer transmission speeds are now typically in the range of 2 400 to 9 600 bits per second with some computers communicating at even higher rates.

The maximum data rate practically achievable on DRCS are 4 800 bits per second. As modems become faster and faster it is not inconceivable that inbuilt mechanisms will prohibit communication below a specified transmission rate. Given that there is no legislative requirement, or otherwise, for analogue or digital systems to be upgraded, the bush may lose the limited service access enjoyed today. This may occur, ironically, as a result of technological advancement.

Further services unavailable to the bush, include caller line identification and itemised billing. Local call access to essential services and communities of interest is unavailable to many remote households. As these examples clearly illustrate the standard service in country areas does not equate to the standard service in urban regions. It can therefore be argued that in some areas service quality is such that Telecom's Universal Service Obligation is not being met. If such obligations are not being met now, there seems very little hope that rural telephone systems will accommodate information services of the future.

Rural and remote Australia may have nothing to gain from competition within the telecommunications market, in fact these regions may have everything to lose. Obviously the pressure on both carriers is to spend capital where it will produce the most revenue—the heavily trafficked routes. Unless there is some enforceable mechanism to ensure that carrier money is also spent to maintain and upgrade the telecommunications network in rural and remote Australia, the ability of the network to deliver new and enhanced services will, over time, diminish.

The enforcement mechanism necessary is a Universal Service Obligation relevant to today's information society. The standard telephone service, as defined in the Act, will become increasingly irrelevant in today's information and technological age.

The definition must be updated to ensure rural and remote Australians have access to a standard of service comparable with the standard of service available to the majority of the people of Australia.
This bill makes the necessary update.
The amendment also provides that if a definition is to be set by regulation the standard or standards so determined must ensure that standards of service are comparable across Australia.

The proposed amendment of section 38 of the Principal Act deals with AUSTEL's general functions and would require that indicative performance standards recognise that services of similar standards should be available to all the people of Australia.

The proposed amendments to section 246 dealing with technical standards would impose a new paragraph (b) to provide for similar standards for all people. The other provisions of section 246 would remain i.e. subsections (1) and (3), (4) and (5). The proposed new section 246 (A) would allow the Minister to give directions to AUSTEL about the performance of its functions in relation to section 246 (the determination of technical standards). This is consistent with the ability of the Minister to give directions to AUSTEL.

The definition of a standard telephone service now in the Act can be changed by regulation. However, given that no such regulations have been prescribed the introduction of this Private Senator's bill aims to trigger the necessary change.

Given that it is argued that Telecom's obligation to provide a standard telephone service to all Australians is currently not being met there is justifiable concern that advancements in telecommunications will bypass the bush. Governments should not shirk from the responsibility of providing equitable and affordable access to information services.

The vast nature of the Australian continent demands governments play a role in the provision of service equity. The Telecommunications (Performance Standards) Amendment Bill 1994 challenges the Government to maintain and improve regional and rural telecommunications.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addition to the incorporation of the second reading speech, I would like to say that we on our side of the chamber regard it as a very important matter that Telecom, as the universal common carrier, should be responsible for ensuring that the people outside the metropolitan areas are able to receive standards of telecommunications service equivalent to those in city areas. In order to do that, it is necessary that it be put in a position where there is, to put it bluntly, parliamentary pressure to ensure that that occurs.

PARA.TAB: There are two distinct sets of problems. One relates to switching gear, and that is a matter Telecom certainly has under control. A condition of its licence is that all local exchanges be converted to digital by 1997. I think the latest Austel figures indicate that some 29 per cent of local exchanges have been digitalised. It is very important that Telecom adheres strictly to that timetable.

If that occurs, then a number of intelligent network features such as caller line identification, voice mail and itemised billing will be available to those in rural and remote areas. That will ensure that they are able to properly calculate whether they have been overcharged or perhaps even undercharged. But certainly such people will have access to the facilities and features that are increasingly becoming available to people in metropolitan areas.

Our concern is not so much in the area of switching but in transmission. The particular problem in that area is that, despite Telecom having spent $530 million through the late 1970s and early 1980s on the rural and remote areas program, people in those areas still experience a number of very significant problems, particularly congestion, call dropouts and general noise and interference. The figures indicate that about 80 per cent of people complain of those sorts of happenings on a reasonably regular basis. Certainly in remote areas the problem is that the digital remote concentrator systems need to be upgraded. There are some high speed concentrators being put in place but I think at a fairly slow rate—about four to date and about two a year over the next five years. But that is certainly not enough. As I understand it, Telecom is frantically conducting research to determine the most appropriate method of upgrading the technology, but there is certainly a long way to go.

The purpose of this bill is to ensure that some form of timetable is identified by Telecom and adhered to. By having the act amended so as to require Telecom to maintain the roughly equivalent standard of service, we would hope that there will not be too great a time lag and that it will therefore recognise that the universal service obligation extends to all Australians.

At least inclusion of the word `must' means that the attention of the licence holder will be directed to each of those conditions when each of those licences is granted. They are just a couple of examples of a number of provisions that the joint authority may require of the licence holder.

Senator Coulter's proposal to substitute `may' for `must' means that a licence holder must follow all the provisions listed, not just the environmental provisions that Senator Coulter is concerned about. That would mean that a licence holder must take out insurance; no discretion is given. It is not necessarily desirable that a licence holder take out insurance in all circumstances.

In relation to the other matter raised, it would also mean that a licence holder must lodge security. Again, that would depend on the circumstances. That is why we have the word `may' there. The comments that I have made in relation to clause 118 apply to the other forms of licensing in the other three clauses that Senator Coulter's amendments apply to. For those two reasons that I have outlined we oppose the amendment as proposed by the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1993 proposes a series of changes, primarily to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, with minor consequential amendments to a series of related acts. It introduces the issue of a seniors health card; restructures some child related payments; imposes a limitation on the Commonwealth's liability, through an adjustment to disability pensions payable, to take account of any lump sum compensation paid for the same injury, disease or death; and introduces changes to the definition of retirement villages, ensuring that accommodation intended primarily for persons over 55 years of age will be taken as accommodation intended for people who are at least 55 years of age. There are provisions for deprivations concerning consideration for an assets test in relation to assets disposed of for up to five years in advance of the application for a pension. There are changes to managed investment rules, and changes with respect to the restitution of a pension where a person complies with a request for a tax file number within three months. There is provision to allow for oral, and not just written, withdrawal of an application to determine the qualifying period for a service pension claim. There are provisions to ensure that a carer's pension may be withdrawn or suspended when not drawn on for six months; and a series of amendments concerning pensioner rate reduction, income test definitions, recovery of overpayments, and finally, a series of consequential, technical and minor amendments to four schedules.

PARA.TAB: Broadly, this legislation fulfils the government commitment to introduce a seniors health card, which will give certain low income veterans not in receipt of a service pension and those who do not meet residency requirements for the age service pension access to concessional pharmaceutical benefits, hearing-aid concessions and an entitlement to dental and optometry services. It is estimated that this will benefit 10,000 veterans and their dependants.

The amendments concerning child-related payments ensure service pensioners receive the same pension payment improvements that have been available for social security pensioners, who gained the benefit of the improvements when child-related payments were integrated into the family payment system. These improvements include the backdating of child-related payments from the date of birth, and a mechanism to allow them to be re-directed to the partner.

There is an amendment dealing with the Commonwealth liability for disability pensions paid under part 2 of the act. This amendment seeks to provide consistency in the arrangements for offsetting compensation payments against a disability pension paid for the same incapacity or death for which compensation is paid under part 2 of the act. An offset arrangement for disability pensions paid under part 4 of the act in respect of defence or certain peacekeeping service has been in force since 1973. The offset arrangements mean that the Commonwealth requires compensation payments and damages recoverable at law from the Commonwealth or otherwise to be offset against any pension payable for the same injury, disease or death. This amendment aligns the offset provisions for disability pensions paid under part 2 in respect of war or operational service.

The section on retirement villages is self-explanatory and removes the ambiguity as to the age at which a person can enter those facilities. The disposition of assets is similarly self-explanatory, taking it back to a period of five years before the application of a pension.

The managed investment rules are to be changed to allow for: the offsetting of losses on realisation of an investment against profits realised on other managed investments; the offsetting of losses on an investment that is subject to an ongoing assessment against income distribution from other managed investments assessed on realisation only; and a formula for calculating the rate of return on an investment when there are multiple declarations for return rates or when only an interim rate of return has been declared. Investments in a friendly society which converts to a life company will not be affected by the change in status if certain criteria are met. There is clarification of a number of provisions relating to the treatment of an annuity for the purpose of an ordinary income test.

I did not mention in my general introduction that contributions to the New South Wales Medically Acquired HIV Trust fund, which has been established to provide assistance to people in New South Wales who have medically acquired HIV, will not be considered as income under the income test. Contributions, therefore, will not affect the donor.

The opposition supports the bill with the exception of those parts of it which relate to managed investments. Quite clearly, there are advantages and disadvantages to veterans coming from the changes proposed in this bill. As my colleague Mr Philip Ruddock said in speaking to the bill in the House of Representatives, there are winners and losers in those clauses. This part of the bill parallels changes which went through last year in social security legislation.Some of those changes were introduced into the Senate in the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), which came before the Senate in the closing days of the session before Christmas. Again, the justification for those changes to be included in the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) was that they were to parallel changes that had already been passed in the social security legislation.

It is history that the decision of the Senate at that time was to reject those changes which affect retirement incomes until the government inquiry into retirement incomes has made its report. That is still the position of the Liberal and National parties today in relation to this bill. We will not support any further changes or amendments to legislation—either veterans' affairs legislation or social security legislation—dealing with managed investments, asset testing or income testing until the complete review of the assets and income test agreed to by the government has been implemented.

The operation of the changes to social security legislation which this bill sets out to replicate for veterans has been adverse to their interests. In plain English, some of them are worse off as a consequence. The current rise in stock market values will have some indirect impact on managed investments because all managed investments are pooled funds and some of their investments could well be in the form of shares. I do not propose to take up the time of the Senate this morning by running through the argument that we went through in considerable detail before Christmas; there is no point in doing that. I will only say that we will not support any changes to factors concerned with retirement income policy until we have seen what the government proposes to do in the light of its inquiry into this matter. We take that position because of the basic unfairness of making changes that are not part of a coherent whole, the effects of which will really disadvantage some people.

The government may be concerned about that. I have no doubt that we will see from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Faulkner) a quite emotional outburst against what he would regard as the unfairness of what we are doing. But I put it to the minister that, if he is concerned about it, the solution lies in his own hands. The government has to accelerate the workings of that committee by giving it the resources and facilities it needs to get on with the job and carry out its task. As soon as that committee reports and the government has considered its response to that report, we will be prepared to consider what the government wants to do.

I note in passing that the implementation of part 2, as clause 2(4) in the introductory part of the bill states, is not to commence until 1 July 1994. So the government has six months of this calendar year to get that committee up and running and reporting. If the government is genuinely concerned to effect legislative change in these areas, then it will see that the inquiry gets the resources that it needs, and it will get on with the job and expeditiously bring the findings of that committee before the Senate. With those few words I conclude my remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we have heard, the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) proposes a number of changes to the Veterans' Entitlements Act, with minor consequential amendments to related acts such as the Hearing Services Act 1991, the National Health Act 1953, the Social Security Act 1991 and the Defence Services Homes Act. The Australian Democrats welcome the introduction of the seniors health card as from July 1994 for certain low income, non-pensioner retirees.

PARA.TAB: Long-term Democrat policy has called for eligibility for pensioner fringe benefits based on the amount of income received and not the source of that income. Self-funded retirees who have made sacrifices throughout their working lives to provide for their own retirement have in the past found themselves at a relative disadvantage compared with age pensioners. We have always argued that self-funded retirees on the same level of income as age pensioners should be entitled to all the benefits available to those pensioners.

As stated by my colleague Senator Woodley last year during the debate on the social security legislation, the Democrats would like to see these people provided not only with health cards but also with the public transport concessions, reductions in telephone and electricity costs, as well as car registration fees and household rate concessions that age pensioners are able to claim. We ask the government once again to consider extending these benefits to independent retirees.

We have consulted with the RSL on the rest of the contents of this bill and it has no major problems with any of the provisions apart from part 7 dealing with managed investments. The Democrats will not be moving any amendments to the bill but we will be opposing the managed investments provisions.

When the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993 came before the Senate in December last year we refused to support the provision relating to allocated pensions and we asked the government not to proceed any further with changes to retirement incomes before we hear the findings of the inquiry into retirement incomes and means testing.

We appreciate that the amendment referring to managed investments might not disadvantage all veterans, but we are not convinced that the formula is adequate to ensure that they will not be out of pocket in the end. In any case, we believe we should be consistent in our call for no more interference in retirement incomes until after the findings of that inquiry. There is no doubt that recent changes have caused a great deal of worry to veterans and elderly Australians and our constant tinkering with their incomes is causing a great deal of anxiety. We are making it very difficult for them to plan ahead.

I again make the point that if we accept more changes to retirement incomes now, then we are assuming that the findings of the inquiry will have no impact on the government's intentions in this area, regardless of any recommendations made. If the inquiry is not a cynical exercise on the part of the government and it does intend to act on its findings, it is not unreasonable to expect that if we inflict this measure on veterans now we will be forced to consider changing it again further down the track. We simply cannot support changes which might not be necessary. We have to wait for this committee to report.

The Democrats were pleased to hear from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Faulkner) that John Barber, formerly of the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants, has been appointed as the independent consultant to this inquiry. We trust that the process will get under way very soon. The inquiry is due to make an initial draft report in July of this year, with the final report in September. It is, therefore, vital that the work of this committee begins as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think even Senator MacGibbon made a grudging admission in this second reading debate that the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) contains many beneficial amendments for the assessment of the service pension and beneficial measures for the veteran community. I am going to disappoint him because, as usual, I am not going to involve myself in any emotional outburst, but will objectively, rationally and reasonably argue the case against the miserable propositions that he put forward.

PARA.TAB: This bill contains amendments that are part of the government's strategy announced in Building on strength: towards a fairer Australia and which seek to improve the position of low income retirees. This strategy is implemented by easing the pension assets test and by introducing a seniors health card. The government fulfilled the first part of this commitment by introducing legislation to ease the pensions assets test from 20 September 1993. Part 2 of this bill meets the second part of the commitment by introducing a seniors health card from 1 July 1994.

The opposition's major concern—and this was reinforced in the contribution made by Senator Bourne—relates to the managed investment provisions of this bill. In particular, the opposition wants to delay any amendment to the income and assets test until the independent review of the income and assets test for service and social security pensions hands down its recommendations.

It has to be placed on record that the income and assets amendments contained in this bill advantage service pensioners. For reasons that I really cannot understand, the opposition—and unfortunately the Australian Democrats are joining it—apparently is seeking to hold up these benefits for service pensioners.

I mention also that failure to include the amendments could put the Veterans' Entitlement Act out of kilter with the Social Security Act and maintain anomalies within the Veterans' Entitlement Act. The government cannot responsibly delay these amendments for two years awaiting the outcome of a review to become law. The independent review will hand down its report in September this year. The government's response will be considered in the context of the 1995-96 budget and announced in that budget. As we all know, the drafting of any amending bill and the passage of such a bill takes time, particularly in this chamber.

The government is keen not to make any major changes until the review has reported, but the effect of the opposition blocking these amendments will result in a piecemeal and inconsistent approach to pension assessment by creating differences and maintaining anomalies. I commend this bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Clauses 1 to 28—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Clauses 29 to 39—by leave—taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clauses 29 to 39 deal with managed investments—part of the area to be inquired into by the committee looking at income and asset testing. Issues relating to managed investments are only one aspect of this inquiry but they are of vital concern to both veterans and pensioners.

PARA.TAB: I accepted in my speech in the second reading debate, as did Senator Bourne on behalf of the Australian Democrats, that there are winners and losers in the implementation of the clauses. We made the point that we do not accept any further piecemeal changes because there will be losers. We think that is basically unfair because we are looking at uncoordinated changes being proposed to retirement incomes. We believe that any changes should be after the review has been completed. For that reason, we will oppose clauses 29 to 39 for the purpose of postponing implementation until we see what the inquiry has had to say on the matter.

I was surprised when the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Senator Faulkner) said there would be a two-year delay in the implementation of retirement incomes. Even by the standards of this government's managerial incompetence, that is a pretty good stretching out of the legislative process. If there was a will to prosecute this matter sincerely and conscientiously, we could be looking at legislation in the middle of the year. If that happens there will be no detriment to anyone's interests at all, because the opening part of this bill calls up a commencement date for one part of the bill of 1 July this year.

Before Christmas we had before us the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2); it was amended in the Senate and went down to the House of Representatives. The House of Representatives did not even consider it, and to call its debate a kangaroo court would be too flattering a description. That place just turned that legislation around straight away and sent it back to us. When the Senate reaffirmed its original position, the government sulked and said that it would not proceed with the bill. It was quite open to the government, in the interests of legislative fairness, to accept the amended bill and then come back with further legislation. That would have overcome any disability to the pensioners and veterans.

I seriously counsel the minister on this occasion to do the same with this bill. I ask him to accept the parts that the Senate is prepared to pass into law and hurry up the committee. Let us get on with the business and clean up the whole of the retirement income issue in the middle of this year. That is a quite attainable goal.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will oppose clauses 29 to 39, basically on the same grounds outlined by Senator MacGibbon on managed investments. It is not good practice to chop and change what happens to the income of self-funded retirees, aged pensioners, anyone who is past the age of earning an income. It does not work and causes a lot of anxiety in the community. I hope that we will soon have the results of the inquiry, after which we will be able to make one change with which we can stick so that we know exactly what is happening. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Faulkner), in a very measured speech—
—As usual.

—As usual, the minister tells me. The minister said, and we agree, that some people will be advantaged by this. But we do not believe that it should be changed before it has to be changed. It needs one final change that people can count on as staying. So we will oppose these clauses and look forward to the results of the inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —These clauses relate to amendments in the management investment area of the legislation. There are three amendments contained in the proposal. The first clarifies the legislation by ensuring that all losses from managed investments can be offset against profits from other managed investments. The original legislation was not clear on this point in respect of some pre-1988 investments. This part of the bill will put the situation beyond doubt.

PARA.TAB: The second amendment ensures that where an investment has been held for less than 12 months, and only an interim rate of return has been declared, that rate will be maintained as the annual rate of return. Applying the current provisions it is possible that the interim rate of return is extrapolated for 12 months. This can result in a higher rate of return being maintained in the service pension assessment than the actual rate of return over a 12-month period. This amendment will clarify the operation of this provision.

The third amendment addresses industry changes occurring to friendly societies, and the effect that this has on certain investments. In the current economic climate a number of friendly societies have changed status. Under the act, a change in status of a friendly society would affect an investment made with that company. The investment would be considered as realised, and any profit that has accrued would be maintained in a person's service pension assessment for 12 months. Income is not assessed on friendly society investments made prior to 1 January 1988 until the investment is realised. If realised, the profit is assessed as income for the 12-month period following the realisation.

This measure would safeguard these investments by providing that where the conditions of the investment remain substantially the same, the current investment rules will apply. Profits from the investment will not be assessed until they are realised by some other method.

As all these measures are beneficial to service pensioners with these forms of investment, it is proposed that these measures commence from 1 April 1993. This date has been chosen as it is the date that a significant number of changes were originally made to this area of pension assessment.

I think it was a very unreasonable point that Senator MacGibbon made during the debate about the timing of the review. The plan is to see the review recommendations announced in September this year. It is very difficult to see that it will occur before then. Then it will be addressed in next year's budget. That is appropriate timing. It cannot be done more quickly than that. Any reasonable or objective observer would accept that that is a proper and appropriate time frame in these circumstances.

I believe that the arguments put forward by the opposition—and unfortunately it has been joined by the Democrats on this occasion—are of very little substance. It is extraordinarily disappointing that those opposite cannot join with the government on this occasion and see these beneficial provisions to service pensioners go through this parliament.
Question put:
That clauses 29 to 39 be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Remainder of bill—by leave—taken as a whole, and agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to take up the time of the Senate unnecessarily by repeating debate from the lower house on the Corporate Law Reform Bill 1993. The bill was debated in that chamber on 1 February and I particularly commend the speech of the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Daryl Williams QC, during the second reading debate to those people who are interested in the detailed provisions of this bill. However, I do want to make a number of general points and, in that sense, repeat some points made by Mr Williams and others in the debate. I also wish to take up one specific point raised by him, which was acknowledged by the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) when he responded to the second reading debate in the other place, but he either glossed over it or simply missed the point—I am not sure which—so I will come back to that.

PARA.TAB: I make the following initial points with respect to this bill. Everyone knows that this is, in effect, a replacement of an earlier attempt that was perhaps not so much a disaster but spectacularly unsuccessful. I do not mention that to be critical of the earlier attempt, but to praise the government for having made some attempt to listen to concerns raised by the business community and legal academics with respect to the consequences of proceeding with the bill in its original form. That point having been made, there are others to make of a general nature.

I note that Mr Williams, in his speech in the other place, acknowledged the cost of new legislation. I see Senator Chris Evans and Senator McKiernan opposite. They are, relatively speaking, new members of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, but no doubt they will remain and be longstanding members of that committee and show a great interest in the committee's main and most important reference, in my view, and that is the cost of justice. They will no doubt be familiar, as is Senator Spindler who is also on that committee, with the point that committee made in its second report.

I take almost every opportunity to repeat this point because it needs to be repeated until everybody in this place understands it, that is, that new legislation is expensive. It is expensive not only in terms of the cost of drafting and the efforts put in by the Public Service to assist the government, and the efforts put in by parliamentarians, who are all paid by taxpayers, to try to do a decent job of this; but also, once the bill is implemented, the people who are affected by it need to re-learn that legislation and that needs to be taken into account as a cost of justice.

When one goes to a lawyer, especially on a corporate matter where one might need accounting advice as well, the law has become so complex that the more we churn out of here the more expensive dealing with such matters is. It is all too easy, as Senators Evans, McKiernan and Spindler and I know, to make the inexpensive assumption that is easily grabbed by the media that the cost of justice is forced up because all lawyers are greedy so and sos who pay themselves far too much. I see Senator Cooney, the chairman of that committee, in here. It is important for us to understand the contribution we make to that cost by continuing to legislate and adding, just about every parliamentary day, to the burden of regulation that lawyers have to find their way through in order to be able to advise their clients. They have to charge to do that because the legal profession is not a charitable institution; it is not meant to be the Salvation Army.

That committee has also made reference to the need for laws to be in plain English and to be simplified. We should try to simplify what we have got instead of adding to the mountain of it, and any new legislation put through should be in plain English. People should be able to open an act of parliament and see what the law is that they are supposed to be following, and lawyers should not have to spend so much time on the detail of one act and comparing it to another.

Support for that type of reasoning is no doubt the reason why the government is engaging in a program of simplification of the Corporations Law. It is to be commended for that if, in fact, it is successful. This raises the question as to why, when the government has embarked upon that program and set up an advisory committee, it is nonetheless proceeding now with this legislation which deals primarily with continual disclosure and prospectuses.

We understand and support the bill. It is important that investors have access to information which enables them to make proper judgments about where they should be putting their money. That does need fixing up. There is no denying that. But at the same time, we have a government that says, `We are going to overhaul the Corporations Law. We are going to simplify it' yet while that simplification process is going on, it is adding to the Corporations Law. It seems as though we are fixing things on the run but adding to what needs to be fixed as we go along. One cannot help but notice that.Mr Williams made this point very early on in his speech in the other place.

Once this bill is passed, regulations and administrative arrangements will have to be worked out. Just consider the range of people that need to be involved—lawyers, accountants, company directors, company secretaries and the courts. They are all going to be dealing with this legislation and the regulations and administrative arrangements that are worked out. Then, should these amendments need to be altered in some way as part of this overall simplification process, all of that learning exercise, all of the expense that has been incurred in terms of people's time and money, simply gets tossed out. The government has yet to give an explanation as to why it is appropriate in these circumstances to move ahead as it is.

Nonetheless, I come back to my original point that at least the government had the brains to consider the quite strenuous criticisms that were put forward as to the original format of this bill. A number of changes have been made, some of which have been advocated consistently by the coalition, and we are pleased about that. When the changes are implemented they will, without a shadow of a doubt, need monitoring—the government acknowledges that because the bill requires the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee to review the operation of continuous disclosure and the related enforcement provisions 18 months after their commencement.

That only raises again the question: where will we be in 18-months time with the simplification process? Will there be a review in 18 months? Will some suggestions for change be made? Will we then, on the basis of that review, want to go ahead and make those changes without resolving the overriding process of simplification and still not knowing where this bill, in its then amended form, will fit in? This is a constant nightmare.

It is worth labouring that point because day after day we hear on talkback programs and read in the papers about the high cost of justice and all the money that commercial lawyers make. Part of the reason they make that money is because we in this place make the law so complex and unwieldy. Mr Williams made the point in the other place—it bears repeating here as well—that complexity or simplification is a very relative thing. It would not matter if we did a 100 per cent first class job and we agreed on an all party basis—including the Democrats as a party, the Independents and the Greens—that we had got the corporations law to its most simple form, it would still be one of the most complex pieces of legislation that we produce in this place. Nonetheless, it would be expensive to administer and expensive to access in order to exercise one's rights. We look forward to seeing what comes out of the review.

The detailed point that I want to raise—it was raised by Mr Williams and either glossed over or missed by Mr Lavarch in his response—relates to prospectuses. Towards the end of his speech during the second reading debate, Mr Williams made this point:

The bill enables a document that purports to have been prepared by the ASC from the database by using a data processor to be admissible in a proceeding in a court as prima facie evidence of the matters stated in it. Certification of the document is not required. The amendment is intended to reduce substantially the circumstances in which routine and expensive formal certification of documents is required in court proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: He went on to say that he was somewhat concerned about the apparent breadth of that provision. It was not entirely clear to him from the wording of the provision how it could operate in practice. He then went on to give examples. He said:

The provision would allow production of the document from the database to prove that the persons on the form were directors of the company at times stated in the document. That could be rebutted by evidence to the contrary. In a similar vein, the provision would be used to adduce evidence of the incorporation of a company, appointments of receiver or liquidator and registration of charges.

He said that he had no problem with those sorts of things, that they are pretty formal matters, but that it is another matter when we turn to some other examples. He said an annual report contains, for example, the accounts of a company. Mr Williams went on to say:
It is not objectionable that the provision should facilitate proof that the annual report was prepared, that it was lodged and that the accounts were signed off.
Then Mr Williams raised the question: what about the truth of the contents of the accounts? He stated:

Under the provision the annual report is admissible as `prima facie evidence of the matters stated in so much as the writing sets out what purports to be information obtained by the Commission'. The effect seems to be that the provision is intended to prove the content of the annual accounts prima facie. That could be done by production of the ASC document without there being available to the party against whom the document is adduced the opportunity to cross-examine a witness who knows something about the accounts.
He went on to say:

PARA.TAB: In the report by the chairman or by the directors contained in most annual reports, contentious assertions of fact are not infrequently made. The effect of the provision appears to make the assertion prima facie proof of the truth of the assertion and not merely proof that the assertion was made. Again, that could be adduced into evidence without there being available to the party against whom the evidence is adduced the opportunity to cross-examine a witness who knows anything about the truth of the assertion.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Williams said that the manner in which the provisions operate in practice will need to be closely monitored to ensure there is not any particular injustice. In relation to that, the Attorney, I do not think in any condescending way, noted that the shadow Attorney made fair comment—it is very gracious of him to acknowledge that Mr Williams was making fair comment—in terms of the matters pertaining to the admissibility into court of information in the database. Mr Lavarch went on and kindly said that he thought Mr Williams put the case well. He also said:

The point is that any evidence which is led in court on the basis of the provisions in this bill is the starting point of a submission to rebut. It is possible to lead evidence to overcome the prima facie nature of evidence which has previously been led. I think the honourable member argued that it would not be possible to bring forward a witness to rebut what was contained in an annual report or a chairman's statement. That is not my understanding of how it would work.
Mr Williams has faxed a note to me and has this to say in response to Mr Lavarch:

The Attorney-General has quite missed my point. I accept that it is open to the party against whom evidence is led . . . to rebut the effect of the prima facie effect of the evidence. But it must be understood that not infrequently the affairs of a company . . . may not be within the knowledge of the other party or any witnesses available to the other party. In those circumstances the other party would be dependent on cross-examination of a witness called by the party leading the evidence to rebut the prima facie effect of the material. Forcing the party asserting a fact to call a witness to prove the fact in order to expose the witness to cross-examination is a much-used and often essential tactic to enable the truth to be elicited and justice done.

That is reasonably clear. I have tried to stick as best I can to what was said. It is a bit boring reading out word for word what someone said but I think each party has put its case fairly clearly. Mr Williams has raised an important concern to which there may be an answer—and the officials may be able to help us. The wording used by Mr Lavarch seems to miss the essential point that Mr Williams has made. We would be very pleased if the minister could deal with that point in his response to the second reading debate. If not, although there are no amendments, we could deal with it at the committee stage to see what we can do to clarify the situation and get some better response to the concern raised by Mr Williams, which is, I think, the most important one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate is discussing the Corporate Law Reform Bill. The main purpose of the bill is to introduce a statutory-based system of continuous disclosure of information by those who issue invitations to the public to invest in securities, together with requirements that these entities submit half-yearly accounting reports. I make the comment that this is not before time.

PARA.TAB: During the late 1980s, and with the financial disasters of that decade, we saw the market's lack of capacity to respond to the justified expectation of investors to be protected from the corporate cowboys who use a buoyant market to bolster their fortunes but who forget about the need to protect the interests of investors. In particular, they forget that capital will not flow through the marketplace unless the marketplace has confidence in the information available to it. So the central provisions of this bill are welcomed.

In addition, the bill reforms prospectus provisions to take account of continuous disclosure; relaxes the present restrictions on companies indemnifying and insuring their officers and auditors; and facilitates the use of Securities Commission databases in court proceedings. It also provides for an improved flow of information between the Securities Commission and the Stock Exchange. Further, it seeks to enable accounting standards to be set in respect of the new disclosure requirements.

The disasters of the 1980s clearly demonstrated that the level of disclosure from relevant bodies was seriously inadequate in relation to both listed and non-listed entities, such as building societies, life offices and building trusts. That was acknowledged by the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee in its report entitled Enhanced Statutory Disclosure systems and by the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in its report The Rights of Shareholders.

The government's response has been slow and inconsistent. First of all, we had the so-called Duffy bill which sought to improve disclosure via the Securities Commission. In 1992, Mr Duffy, the then Attorney-General, introduced the Corporate Law Reform Bill (No. 2) 1992, which ultimately lapsed. The central theme of that bill was to introduce an enhanced statutory disclosure system to be administered by the Securities Commission. The scheme was to be additional to the requirements of the Stock Exchange and was to apply also to non-listed entities.

There were three criticisms of that bill: it duplicated reporting requirements—namely, those of the Securities Commission and the Stock Exchange; it created a discrepancy in reporting time frames—it specified both immediate disclosure and disclosure within three days; and it allowed the withholding of confidential or commercially sensitive information—a loophole one could drive a coach-and-four through.

We now have the present Attorney-General's approach—the Lavarch approach—which rests basically on the principle of self-regulation. I have some difficulties with that. Self-regulation does not seem to work all that well in the legal profession. I wonder why we are prepared to entrust the fortunes of our financial markets and investors—indeed, the whole issue of the probity and integrity of our capital market—to self-regulation. It seems to me that, in many ways, this is a bit like leaving the wolf in charge of the flock: stockbrokers will be monitoring stockbrokers.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, in its report on corporate practices and the rights of shareholders, recommended that a regime of continuous disclosure by listing companies be enforced; that it be enforced through the Stock Exchange by revised listing rules; and that the Stock Exchange be given stronger statutory support under the Corporations Act.

The legislation presently before us takes the line favoured by the committee and, as I said, is very heavily in favour of the principle of self-regulation—certainly at least as far as listed companies are concerned—by giving legislative sanction to listing rule 3A and leaving the Stock Exchange largely in charge of compliance. The bill will require disclosure information that is not generally available—that is commendable—and which a reasonable person would expect to have a material effect on the price or value of the security of the listed entity. In relation to non-listed entities, the bill provides for a statutory scheme of continuous disclosure to the Securities Commission.

As I said before, this bill appears to leave the wolf in charge of the flock. I must say that there is little reason for confidence. The record of the Stock Exchange during the 1980s in ensuring compliance with the reporting requirements of its own rules was not good. The question must be asked: can the Stock Exchange do better this time?

There are measures in this bill that strengthen the hand of the Stock Exchange and which may make it more active. I emphasise the word `may'—it depends on whether it has the will to ensure compliance. Firstly, the Stock Exchange need not give an undertaking as to damages when seeking a court order in a breach of its rules; secondly, the Stock Exchange is given the protection of qualified privilege when it publishes material supplied under the disclosure scheme; and, thirdly, there is a provision for enhanced information flow between the Stock Exchange and the Securities Commission.

Also welcomed is provision for shareholders to sue. Listed or unlisted entities who respectively fail to notify the Stock Exchange or the Securities Commission of relevant information can be sued by a person who suffers a loss as a result. Listed or unlisted entities who respectively fail to notify the Stock Exchange or the Securities Commission of relevant information can also be subject to criminal liability.

However, it seems to the Australian Democrats that even more safeguards may be needed. One would be an earlier reporting date. The bill requires the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee to review the operation of the disclosure provisions after 18 months of operation, with a requirement that it report within a further six months. That gives us a two-year time scale before we have another hard look at whether this system works. Given the Stock Exchange's poor record during the 1980s, the enormous responsibilities vested in the Stock Exchange by this bill, and the present buoyancy of the market, that review should be taken much sooner. We request the government to consider having this done within 12 months.

It is important that the committee review quickly whether self-regulation is ensuring compliance with the disclosure provisions. There are some areas where the bill leaves massive discretions to the Stock Exchange board which, in our view, should have been addressed in the legislation. The absence of carving-out provisions is the most obvious example. The bill allows for the formulation of carve-out provisions by the Stock Exchange through its listing rules. Apparently, the Stock Exchange has said that it intends to consider express confidentiality provisions for the listing rules, but there is no legislative time frame for that to be done. This prospect raises the spectre of the bill being weakened considerably in its provisions. One cannot be entirely confident that the Stock Exchange will not provide gaps for people who want to evade the disclosure provisions.

One of the ways to make the Stock Exchange system of self-regulation more responsive and more accountable would be to look at the membership of the Australian Stock Exchange board. The board has 15 members, all drawn from the stockbroking or the business community. Given that these disclosure provisions are intended to protect investors—whether they are large institutional investors combining the funds of many private investors, or individual people who entrust their savings to our capital markets—it would seem to be an obvious move for the Stock Exchange to widen the representation of its board. The Australian Democrats will be pressing that this be done. We believe that there should be representation from the Australian Shareholders Association, from funds managers and from consumer organisations.

We trust that this request is taken seriously. I would have preferred to have seen it in the bill but, seeing that this was not taken up and seeing that we have a prospective time frame of two years, the government should seriously consider urgently requesting the Australian Stock Exchange board to widen its representation in the way in which I have outlined.

We also have the process to simplify the Corporations Law. Senator Vanstone welcomed it, and so do I. It would be highly desirable to have laws which enable ordinary investors—the mums and dads of our investment community—to look up the rules under which they entrust their moneys to the capital markets, and to take whatever action is necessary to preserve their interests. We certainly are not there now.

While it could be argued that it is somewhat incongruous that this bill is brought in before the process of review and simplification of the Corporations Law as a whole is undertaken, time is of the essence. We need to move to provide as much protection as we can. Although the Australian Democrats have certain concerns about the way in which it is being done in this bill, it is important to move as quickly as possible and we will support this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Corporate Law Reform Bill 1993. As my colleague Senator Vanstone has already said, the coalition supports this bill. I wish to make some general comments about the future of corporate governance. I rise because essentially my background is as a director of many companies; public listed companies, public unlisted companies, private companies, government business enterprises and companies limited by guarantee.

PARA.TAB: In my experience, corporate governance is a very important matter for the future of the economy of Australia. The theme of my remarks to the Senate today is to urge the government to hurry up with the process of simplification of corporate law. The limited liability public company has been an enormous success in the world; firstly in separating owners and managers and secondly, in more recent times, in separating specialist investors who provide the capital from the specialist managers who know how to use it.

Throughout to world shareholders are re-examining their relationships with company managers—which is corporate governance. We have seen many big companies get into trouble around the world, and we have also seen trouble with managers. The Maxwell affair was world famous. We also saw IBM get into trouble. The system needs checks and balances. Managers need the freedom to get on with the job. We need a system where we can change managers when they fail to do the job properly. But we also need to encourage investors by having a liquid market.

My major point is that we must keep reminding ourselves that the capital and financial markets are now completely international; thus we cannot simply be talking of an Australian-only market for capital and finance. The larger Australian companies are now international companies. Unfortunately, the government has been doing its best in recent times to make them even more so by tending to drive them offshore with their investments. Instances late last year were the Industrial Relations Act and the Native Title Act. These acts will give further incentive to major companies to invest not in Australia, but offshore.

Getting back to international competitiveness: corporate governance within Australia must be internationally competitive. We cannot isolate ourselves from the rest of the world. In recent years Canada, the United States of America and, in particular, New Zealand—countries with which we compete for investment funds—have modified their corporate governance legislation and they have much simpler systems than ours. Those systems are essentially based on principles, and not on detailed black letter law.

I urge the government to review the situation in Australia and try to head in that direction. We have a very complex Corporations Law. Over the last three years the government has added something like 1,500 pages of law to corporations legislation. It is getting as bad as the tax act.

The coalition welcomes the announcement by the Attorney-General last September that the government is about to embark on an ambitious program of simplification of the Corporations Law. I hope we end up getting a law based on principles—so-called fuzzy law—and not detailed black letter law. The courts can interpret the details in particular instances. We urge the government to get on with that process. The business community in general welcomes these amendments. The coalition welcomes the amendments, and we support the bill.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development)

When I came into the chamber I did not expect I would be leading for the government in a debate on a bill of this importance. I am delighted to have the privilege; nonetheless, it was a surprise.

PARA.TAB: Against that background, I have listened carefully to the debating points raised by honourable senators. There is broad unanimity that this bill is supported, and I thank both the opposition and the Australian Democrats for those indications of support. I also acknowledge, however, that in forging that consensus different reasons have been advanced by the other parties as to why they do so, and different emphases have been placed on the importance of company law reform as it is seen by them. The Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch), in putting this bill forward, has committed himself to an ongoing process of further consultations and continuing reform, and sees himself acting in consort with the heads of agreement between the Commonwealth, the states and the Northern Territory on corporate regulation. TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps `argument' is a bit harsh.

—`Argument' is probably the right word. In lay usage, it has connotations of dispute, and in parliamentary jargon it is probably heated debate and acrimonious dispute. What is true here is that, whilst it is an argument, it is a considered and reasoned argument; a reflective and respectful exchange between two members of the other house, both of whom are lawyers—in the case of the shadow minister, a respected QC from Western Australia. As to the Attorney-General, he is a lawyer of significance in his own right and is advised, of course, by senior law officers of the Commonwealth—
—I mean no disrespect, but he did not practise much longer than I did. I think you are stretching it a bit.

PARA.TAB: The debate in the House of Representatives can be said to have not concluded—to put the fairest view forward—because Senator Vanstone has been able to read into the Hansard record a further contribution to it by the shadow Attorney-General. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—When the bill goes into committee, I think Senator Ellison might want to put the case outlined by Mr Williams and perhaps make a few other points. The introduction of this provision will substantially reduce the circumstances in which routine and expensive formal certification of documents is required in court proceedings.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that consultations are presently going on within the Senate. If there are any other questions, perhaps I could deal with them and come back to this question later. If not, I might just whistle dixie for a few minutes until those consultations conclude because that could aid me in answering the honourable senator's question.

—If I might make an observation, I think that where any intended legislation talks of a presumption it should be approached with care. We are here talking about a presumption that these documents will be prima facie proof of the contents thereof. I understand that it was stated earlier that one could always lead evidence to rebut the content of the documents. The point, however, is this that, certainly in criminal proceedings, there is no onus at all on the accused. The golden thread of our judicial system is that the accused does not have to prove anything; that the accused is innocent until proven guilty.

PARA.TAB: This casts an onus on the accused person to rebut any documentation. That may be all very well, but what happens if the contents of the document are not widely known? What is the position if the contents of a document—for example, the affairs of a company—only fall within the competent knowledge of a few witnesses who are not available to the accused? The proposed section is saying that when this document is produced it will be prima facie evidence of what is in the document. The person on the receiving end would not know enough about the company or its affairs to rebut the contents of the document and that puts that person at a disadvantage.

I ask the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Senator Cook) to address that point in any future answer. Could the minister give me some idea as to whether that is how he sees the clause working, whether any problems arise from that, and whether the principle of a presumption in criminal proceedings is a desirable one? I might have to wait for that to be answered along with the other two questions I raised.
