TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —The consultations that I earlier referred to are continuing outside the Senate chamber. I have no idea how much longer they will take or whether they will conclude satisfactorily to enable me to answer the senator's question. To go to the last matter raised by Senator Ellison, it seems to me that this legislation is addressing the question of how one satisfactorily proves in proceedings the existence of company records germane to those proceedings. This legislation proposes that if one obtains a print-out on a particular company from the database of the Australian Securities Commission, that print-out is accepted as evidence.

PARA.TAB: Senator Ellison seems to be asking whether that should be accepted as evidence and whether it is legitimately able to be accepted as evidence. He also raised the question of presumption. On my understanding of the procedure, companies are required to lodge their records with the Securities Commission. If one wanted to prove the existence of a particular document in a legal proceeding, one could, if one wished, go to the company, obtain the document and have it certified and proved as the company document. That is one way of doing it. I do not imagine that this legislation prevents people from doing that if they so wish.

We should remember that the behaviour of takeover merchants and the abuse of company law has given rise to public concern and has led to better scrutiny of company law proceedings. That is what has brought us to this point. It seems to argue for a removal of technicality if it in no way endangers the rights of any of the parties to litigation. Removal of the technicality here means that, rather than going to the company source, people can actually go to the Securities Commission where companies lodge their records, obtain a print-out of the particular company's records and have that recognised as evidence or as the official documentation. From the government's point of view, that seems to be a satisfactory arrangement and a reasonable basis for having documents recognised as the documents in the proceedings.

When the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) was questioned on this point in the House, he said, in effect, `It does not preclude the leading of evidence about those documents; that is open to the parties in a proceeding if they choose'. That seems to be the belt that goes with the braces—ensuring that the document before a court is the official document in question.

We could argue this back and forth but, with respect, this is a point that the government has undertaken to examine further. If it is satisfied about the veracity of the point, it will propose an amendment in further legislation. We have taken on board the learned intervention of the shadow Attorney-General and honourable senators. We are not dismissing it or rejecting it. We will properly and appropriately consider it. If there are further entreaties or arguments to be put directly to the Attorney-General outside the chamber, they can also be entered into. We will then amend this legislation further in a portfolio bill to be brought forward later this year.

Senator Vanstone has re-entered the chamber. Under special leave at the end of the second reading debate she asked, in effect, why we do not fix it up now rather than waiting until later in the year. I commend Senator Vanstone for seeking efficient consideration of these things. It is a matter on which I will need to take advice from the Attorney-General, and I am not aware of his availability. I notice that the shadow Attorney-General is here. This is not a new point; the omission has not suddenly appeared with startling clarity. Rather, it is an old point on which there has been a lot of tired argument and consideration. It may be that it is not possible to fix it up on the run.

Certainly the government, in making company law, would not want to be in any position where it is accused of changing its legislation in such a manner. It would rather be guilty of more sombre and considered weighing of the particular circumstances and making change, if in somewhat a lumbering way, nonetheless, in a fair and just way. I am not aware of whether it is possible to fix it up. There is no sign of the consultees returning to the chamber, which leaves me with the question that Senator Ellison first put to me. I understand that question has a technical answer, but consultations may inform me better about that technical answer.I will be interested to see whether there are any further interventions by honourable senators. If not, I will do my best to answer Senator Ellison's earlier question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Flowing from my earlier point—and it might assist the advice the minister is getting—I will give an example of how this provision would work. I was involved in a case where company minutes and documents were used in a prosecution. They were relevant to the prosecution case. It was the argument of the accused that these documents contained incorrect information and that another person had deliberately done this in an effort to blacken him and frame him—to set him up, if you like. There was a good deal of argument about these records and documents.

PARA.TAB: He was lucky to the extent that he had an intimate knowledge of the workings of the company and was able to give evidence as to the detail contained therein, but if this provision is passed it would mean that those documents would have been accepted as prima facie evidence; that is, on the face of it, that the contents are true and correct. It would then be up to the accused person to rebut it, bearing in mind that an accused person under our judicial system has no onus whatsoever to prove anything, and it is up to the prosecution to prove everything. So these documents—these figures and details—would be accepted, on the face of it, as being correct.

What of the situation where the accused does not have sufficient information to be able to rebut that? The person I represented was lucky enough to have the intimate knowledge to do so. But if he had not had that, if it had been the recording of details which were not personally within his knowledge but which indirectly prejudiced him and affected his position, then he would have been hamstrung because he would not have been able to bring any evidence to rebut it. He would have been facing the fact that the document, on the face of it, would be accepted as prima facie evidence; that is, the document speaks for itself.

Normally, that is not the case. Normally one has to bring along the author to certify a document and give that evidence. That is why I am highlighting the point. It is really a fine point, but when we are dealing with matters of proof in evidence we have to deal with fine points because they are really the points that can convict or acquit. When we are dealing with a person's liberty we have to tread very carefully.

I say to the minister that I am mainly looking at the criminal jurisdiction because that is where strict proof has always been required; that is where the case has to be proved beyond a reasonable doubt to convict the accused. I say that so that the minister can see the relevance of my question in relation to what sort of documents we are talking about and what would be on this database. If it is just the registration of a company, that is normally not a controversial document, but it is when one delves into company records and returns that it could become controversial. That is why I asked the question earlier about what documents would be contained in this database.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Department of Health: Alleged Breach of Privacy Guidelines

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Health. —Senator Reynolds, who no doubt has seen the article, would have been as appalled as I was at the prospect that it might be true. When I saw the article I immediately asked for a report. If indeed names had been given at an AAT hearing, it would have been a very serious breach of our privacy rules.

PARA.TAB: The article by Jennifer Cooke on 15 January in the Sydney Morning Herald actually reported that a Melbourne law firm, which represented the families of some people who had died of CJD following human pituitary hormone treatment, had raised this alleged breach in a letter to the Privacy Commissioner dated 7 January.

Unfortunately, the journalist concerned did not check the information with anyone in my department and, as far as I am aware, not with the AAT either. It was a very serious allegation. I contacted the departmental officers and quickly discovered that, while the allegation may have been serious, it was also outrageous, since not one patient's name had been mentioned at the hearing. Moreover, the mention of names in documents tabled at the hearing had been subject to suppression orders. Even those who had their names appear in a document had been given protection by the AAT. The transcript of the hearing confirms the fact that no patient names were mentioned in evidence before the AAT.

Last Saturday the Sydney Morning Herald carried a correction which acknowledged this but, as in all the circumstances when newspapers get it wrong, the article was big and the correction very small. The law firm involved, Rennick Gaynor Kiddle Briggs, has laid itself open to allegations of deliberate mischief or unprofessional conduct. It was this firm's action in releasing correspondence to the Sydney Morning Herald which resulted in that newspaper naming one of the firm's clients, despite this professed concern for privacy.

The firm also released to the press information received under discovery in relation to pending court cases. That material, I might say, was subject to confidentiality undertakings by all concerned, including the firm. It is, however, this practice of putting out newspaper advertisements advising people not to appear before the inquiry until they have spoken to this particular law firm that causes me even greater concern. There is a case, I suppose, for everyone chasing a dollar in the capitalist system, but it ought to have proper limits. The proper limits ought to be protection for those who need it—and certainly those who have been involved in this exercise, at the very least, require their names to be protected. But more than that, it requires some commitment to finding out the truth, not to attempting, by any means, to mar that discovery.

—I refer the Minister for Defence to an advertisement in the Australian dated 29 January 1994 for a defence trade commissioner based in Jakarta, and ask: does the Australian government have a policy of sanctioning, and even promoting, sales of military equipment to any nation that wishes to buy, or are there conditions or restrictions placed on Australian arms sales? —To answer part two of Senator Margetts's question, the Australian government does not regard Indonesia as a threat to Australia's security. To answer part three of her question, any export of defence equipment anywhere outside Australia takes into account a number of factors, not the least of which is a country's human rights record. On the whole, our attitude to defence exports and the controls on those has been stated by this government on many occasions. I suggest that Senator Margetts might like to avail herself of the document that is produced and updated regularly which indicates the processes we go through before any defence equipment is exported.

PARA.TAB: It is really a two-level process. Any manufacturer in Australia that wishes to export defence equipment seeks approval in principle. That is considered by an interdepartmental committee, with representatives from the Department of Defence, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and, I think, the Attorney-General's Department. This committee considers these particular matters and makes recommendations to me, as the final arbiter, and they are approved or not approved. That is not where the process finishes. When those companies make a final agreement to export any military equipment—either lethal or non-lethal—they are required again to seek approval and again go through that process, and the application is finally arbitrated on by me or otherwise.

We have been quite conscious of taking advice from the specialists in this particular field and from Senator Evans's department on what the circumstances are in a particular country. It is no secret at all that we have a total embargo on either lethal or non-lethal arms sales to countries such as Burma. That is already a judgment that we make.

PARA.TAB: As I said constantly throughout the period of the Gulf War, there were many lessons to be learnt from the indiscriminate sales of any weapons platform whatsoever into regions of instability. This government takes the attitude that it will not export arms into regions of instability. Hence at the moment we do not export any arms to Iraq, Iran, Jordan, Syria or Israel. If Senator Margetts took the time to go ahead and read the documentation rather than mouth platitudes, she would understand that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Senator Gareth Evans keeps on saying that Mr Keating's piggery is none of our business and that the Australian people are not entitled to be told the truth about it. Are the Australian people entitled to know the size of the financial obligation Mr Keating's half-owned companies owe to John Brown, his former ministerial colleague who has lobbied this government on behalf of various interest groups and has been and is a government appointee to official positions? In view of the four different versions of the debt owed to John Brown revealed in the Prime Minister's piggery group's chaotic accounts, ranging from $4 1/2 million to nil, will the Minister tell the Australian people how much their Prime Minister's companies really owe Mr John Brown? Is it sensible for our Prime Minister to be under a multi-million dollar obligation to a lobbyist and government appointee?

—Mr President, it might be the business of Senator Baume, or it might be the parliament's business or it might be the public's business if any credible evidence were led to suggest that the Prime Minister was involved in something that amounted to a direct and inappropriate conflict of interest between private interest and public duty. But no such evidence is suggested in this case, any more than there has been any evidence to support the allegations that Senator Baume has made in the past about a conflict of duty in relation to AQIS, a conflict of duty in relation to FIRB, a conflict of duty in relation to seeking particular private tax exemptions. Senator Baume was wrong on all of those occasions. He embarked on a completely half-baked series of theorisings about allegations here and there which had no substance whatsoever.

PARA.TAB: Again, there is no basis whatsoever for justifying any kind of intrusion into the privacy of the Prime Minister and the financial institutions with which he is dealing in terms of the financing of this particular affair, any more than there is any more justification for intruding into the dollar sums that lie behind the honourable senator's own financial interests which he has failed to disclose because he and the rest of his party refuse to put their interests on the register.

It has never been suggested by either side of the house in this parliament that it is appropriate to put on these registers the dollar sums of particular loans that are involved. If financial interests are involved that are appropriate and are part of those to be listed in the public disclosure provisions, then they will be listed as they always have been listed in the past by our side but not by those opposite. Senator Baume has a real cheek, a real hide, to come into this place, having refused with the rest of his colleagues to declare his own interests, to make allegations of this kind about alleged or possible conflict of interest which have no more substance than any previous such allegation he has made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind Senator Evans that the facts of this debt were not revealed by the Prime Minister; they were revealed by my request to the Australian Securities Commission to ensure that at last the Prime Minister's company provide annual reports that had not been provided for the three years of its existence. I once again ask Senator Evans whether he believes it is in the public interest to know whether the Prime Minister, through his family companies, is under an obligation to a lobbyist and someone who has government appointments. I also ask: has any of this $4.5 million actually been paid, or is the lower level of $2.76 million revealed in the latest accounts—which of course only appeared because of my pressure—simply a written-down value because of provisions made against it? Is the public entitled to know the truth, which has been reluctantly dragged out of the Prime Minister's companies at last?

—Mr President, as I understand it the situation is that the Prime Minister has an equity interest of something around the sum of $400,000 in this particular company. The company itself has a debt of the order of $20-odd million. It has assets which are roughly equivalent to that amount of debt, as I understand it, as I am advised—I am not an auditor, I am not an accountant; I do not propose to go into that. There is a suggestion, of course, that there be some extension of that debt as part of an extension of this highly viable and legitimate economic enterprise which has been the subject of rave reviews from Mr Greiner when he was Premier, and to this day from Mr Armstrong, the Minister for Primary Industry in New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: The details of those particular debts—the financial institutions, the banks to which they are owed—is a matter of commercial process involving the company itself. It is not a matter of Senator Baume's business or anyone's business to ask questions about in this way. If Senator Baume has any credible basis to suggest that the Prime Minister is involved in any conflict of interest between his private interests and his public duty, he is perfectly able to say so, but just sort of skirmishing around and raising issues of this kind in the half-baked fishing expedition way in which he is presently involved does him no more credit than any of his previous half-baked and wrong excursions.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —If I might intervene at this point, I have been concerned over some time at what appears to be the possible abuse of parliamentary privilege, both in the Senate chamber and in committee hearings. This is not a concern that is as recent as my accession to the presidency—it is long standing. I draw the attention of honourable senators to resolution 9 of the resolutions on parliamentary privilege agreed to by the Senate on 25 February 1988. Under the heading `Exercise of Freedom of Speech', the resolution states:

INTERJECT.PARA: (1) That the Senate considers that, in speaking in the Senate or in a committee, Senators should take the following matters into account:

PARA.TAB: (a) the need to exercise their valuable right of freedom of speech in a responsible manner;
(b) the damage that may be done by allegations made in Parliament to those who are the subject of such allegations and to the standing of Parliament;
(c) the limited opportunities for persons other than members of Parliament to respond to allegations made in Parliament;
(d) the need for Senators, while fearlessly performing their duties, to have regard to the rights of others; and
(e) the desirability of ensuring that statements reflecting adversely on persons are soundly based.

INTERJECT.PARA: (2) That the President, whenever the President considers that it is desirable to do so, may draw the attention of the Senate to the spirit and the letter of this resolution.

While it must always be the right of senators to seek information on which to form judgments about how well ministers are doing their jobs or on whether the decisions of a particular minister are subject to improper influence, senators should think very seriously, and in accordance with the privilege resolution I have just referred to, before levelling accusations of serious wrongdoing against ministers, senators, or, for that matter, anyone. The increasing practice of senators making a series of unsubstantiated allegations and throwing mud in the hope that some will stick is, I believe, frequently an abuse of parliamentary privilege.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you told Keating that?

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to resolution 9 in the hope that they will consider the long-term implications of what they are doing for the public standing of the Senate. I call Senator McKiernan.

—Mr President, can I ask on what basis you have chosen to make that pronouncement? It would seem to me it is no coincidence that you did it immediately after a question relating to Mr Keating and his financial affairs was brought before this chamber. As I understand it, what you have sought to do, Mr President, is to say that it is not proper for members of this chamber to bring forward unsubstantiated allegations. I think we would all agree with that. But I ask you: on what basis are you in a position to decide that these are unsubstantiated allegations, and, therefore, what is the relevance of bringing this matter up immediately after a question asked by Senator Baume on a matter which clearly gets under the skin of the government?

—On the same point of order, Mr President: I would seek an assurance from you that that statement from the chair does not relate in any way, other than by coincidence, to the question I just asked, which in fact did not involve any `unsubstantiated allegations' but quoted material from the Australian Securities Commission relating to a debt.

—Mr President, it is Senator Gareth Evans who has been saying that allegations are unsubstantiated, so it could be just as easily taken as a reference to what Senator Evans said rather than what Senator Michael Baume said. But if this matter is to be taken further, it should be taken further at the Procedure Committee. If there is any doubt about the appropriateness or otherwise of questions—and I am not saying one way or the other—it should be looked at by the Procedure Committee. It is meeting later today; refer it there and have a discussion there. Something may come of it; nothing may come of it.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. In relation to standing order 7, the raising of matters of privilege, is it not the intent of that standing order to protect people outside this parliament rather than people inside the parliament who have particular remedies within these two chambers? Would you consider that in referring it to the standing orders committee?

—I was referring to resolution 9 on parliamentary privilege agreed to by the Senate on 25 February 1988. I made it clear at the outset that I was making a general comment and that I have been concerned over a long period, not simply since I have been President. The reason why I raised it at that point was that it seemed an appropriate point at which to raise it because there was some contention about the accuracy of comments being made on both sides. I call Senator McKiernan.

—Mr President, does that mean that the next time someone says, `I don't accept the allegations' or `I don't agree with the facts' you are going to stand and, in effect, warn someone not to ask a question of that nature again? I would have thought that was a clear case of intimidation. What we have been told from the chair is that if you make a judgment that a matter is unsubstantiated, you will effectively warn a senator. I would have thought that highly improper. I ask you again: was the decision to give this warning of yours when you did made before you came into this chamber? In other words, had you already decided that the next time there was a question relating to the Prime Minister's financial interests you were going to effectively warn Senator Baume?
—I have made a general statement, which I suggest you read in Hansard tomorrow, when you will have a clearer idea of the full implications of what I said.

—On a point of order, Mr President: you called me to ask a question. You then took Senator Alston's point of order, when I had not heard him call a point of order. In fact, Senator Alston did not raise a point of order but actually put a question to you.
—I apologise, but in the flurry of activity it seemed more appropriate to have this debate fully concluded.

—On a point of order, Mr President: I stress the point made by Senator Watson on paragraph (c), that the resolution refers to people other than members of parliament. I think it is important that you answer some of the questions which have been raised. Mr President, you are the head of a faction of the Labor Party; the interests of the Prime Minister in a piggery are contentious; and you chose to intervene in the debate after a question about the piggery. Could you make it crystal clear to this chamber why you chose to intervene at that point and to whom your remarks were directed, so we are better able to debate this issue?
—I have already responded to that and answered the question that you put to me. That is not a point of order. You put a question to me and I have responded to it already.

—My question somewhat changes the tone of questioning we have had in this place during this question time. It concerns a matter of policy and is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer to the unemployment figures released earlier today, which I welcome and which I understand are much better than market expectations. Can the minister provide the Senate with any further information about the latest unemployment figures? Do those figures indicate any discernible trend or trends? In view of those better unemployment figures, does the minister accept recent criticism of the government's economic policy?

—Today's news of a reduction in Australia's unemployment rate to 10.6 per cent is welcome. In January, employment grew by 22,000. This represents the fifth month in a row that employment has grown in Australia, and employment is now at its highest level since August 1990. Today's figure is, of course, better than market expectation.
—Is market expectation the test?

—Market expectation is not the test but it is an indication. Following the last few months of good results, many people expected a less good result than the previous month. We got a better result than expected, which is good for optimism and confidence in the Australian community.

PARA.TAB: In March last year, the government made a commitment to create 500,000 new jobs in three years. We are well on target to achieve that with growth of nearly 150,000 in the 10 months since that commitment was made. The increase in part-time employment of 48,700 was shared equally by men and women. In trend terms, both male and female part-time and full-time employment are rising.

Whilst I acknowledge that we should not get too carried away with today's figures, nevertheless the improvement is welcome and continues the trend of good economic news in recent weeks. That compares with the amazing statement by the shadow Treasurer today where he described the unemployment figures as the `blood of the unemployed'. Mr Downer, as shadow Treasurer, is getting quite desperate to find a point to make when he starts using phrases such as the `blood of the unemployed' when we have a clearly discernible trend that employment is improving and unemployment is going down.

We still accept, of course, that unemployment is unacceptably high and that there is a risk that the most disadvantaged in the labour market will be left behind unless we assist them to improve their job skills and attractiveness to employers. That is the challenge the government is constructively dealing with at the moment in considering the employment statement, the industry statement and the regional strategy.

Referring to the last part of Senator McKiernan's question, the criticism we are getting from people such as Mr Downer takes no account of the fact that in the macro-economic settings we have low inflation, low interest rates, declining unemployment and investment going up. We are in one of the best periods of economic growth in Australia in a long time. It is a pity that honourable senators opposite seem to be more stuck on listening to the economic policies of Senator Bronwyn Bishop—those mad, lunatic ideas—than to what is really going on in the economy. Clearly, the business community in particular is turning away from the policies or the non-policies of those opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in that capacity and as Minister representing the Minister for Resources. In light of his admission on Tuesday that the current industrial action in the coal industry is pointless, I ask: firstly, does he believe that the industry's productivity, and therefore its chance to hold jobs and expand markets, would be improved if its industrial relations arrangements were absorbed into the national industrial relations system? Secondly, the minister will be aware that the Minister for Industrial Relations has indicated he will introduce legislation to reform the coal industry's industrial relations system. What does the minister understand to be the timetable for this legislation, and what will be its content and implications for the improved performance of the nation's coalmining operations?

—I must comment on the use of the word `admission'. I thought all I was doing was simply stating the fact that the industrial action that is being contemplated at the moment, in the view of the government, would not be productive. I am quite happy to restate that, as there has been further press comment on industry concern about the prices recently negotiated for Australian coal. I know that the Minister for Resources has been in contact with the unions concerned and will take the opportunity to reiterate the government's view that the action would undermine a great deal of the progress that has been made. The union has been part of that, bringing more efficiencies into the coal industry.

PARA.TAB: The important point to make, as far as the negotiators were concerned—and I am sure Senator Sandy Macdonald would agree—is the need to maintain our market share in that market. In competition with competitors such as the Canadians, there was very little option in terms of the price that was set—effectively by them—other than to succeed as we did in maintaining that market share.

The matter mentioned by Senator Macdonald about industrial arrangements being made, I can confirm. The position of the government has been enunciated by the Minister for Industrial Relations. That matter is currently being considered by the government. Discussions will be held between the relevant ministers responsible for the coal industry—the Minister for Resources particularly—and the Minister for Industrial Relations. The government will make statements concerning the outcome of those negotiations when they are concluded.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Prior to Mrs Kelly taking over the sport portfolio in 1990, the minister administered the earlier rounds of the community recreational and sporting facilities program, as it was then called. What administrative process did he use for allocating funds under this process? How did it differ from the process used by Mrs Kelly? What sort of documentation did he keep? Is it still available? Could he provide to the Senate a breakdown of the grants by electorate for each of the rounds that he administered.
—I do not recall ever seeing a breakdown by electorate when I was in the ministry, although I was asked a question in the Senate—by Senator Parer, I think—which referred to such a breakdown.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just take three deep breaths. I am trying to answer the question. I do not actually recall seeing a breakdown by electorate other than that which was referred to me in a question.
—What about Ron Edwards?

—Well, he probably lobbied very hard, Senator. I did not use a whiteboard. I did, however, make the grants from my office. As to what records are there, I do not know, but I will make inquiries to see what they are. There certainly was documentation for each grant but obviously I would not be expected to recall what that documentation was. I will make some inquiries to find out. I administered, I think, $13 million over a couple of years, so it was on a somewhat smaller scale than the current operation. I did not, so far as I can recall, use a whiteboard.
—What did you use? A process of elimination?
—I think in many cases we had some reference from the department about the grants. We then made decisions at the end of the day.
—On what criteria?

—There were laid down criteria at the time, as I recall. I will try to get a copy of that as well for Senator Kernot. I will see whether I can find out what we did and let Senator Kernot know at the next question time. I told her the process: we had a number of grant applications; the department had a look at them; they came into the office; and I, as minister, made the decisions.
—On a process of elimination?

—We had to look through them and determine which ones we thought were most worthy. On that occasion I think Senator Kernot will find that there were fewer applications than there were this time. As I said, there was not as much money. So it was probably not on the same scale.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister going to make any inquiries as to whether he has documentation which shows the grants made by electorate? If he does have it, will he provide it to the Senate?

—Yes, that is correct. I will find out if there was a breakdown by electorate. I do not think there was. I think one was done by the opposition at some point. I was pretty sure it was Senator Parer, but in looking over here, he looks as though he is innocent. But I do recall being asked some sort of question on this. I will check that out. If there is any information of a breakdown by electorate, I will give it to Senator Kernot.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Health. Is Senator Richardson aware that patients who are treated by general practitioners for skin cancer receive a low Medicare refund if the skin cancer is treated by curettage and is not seen by a specialist? Why is Medicare discriminating against general practitioners, especially those in rural areas?

—There was some controversy about this, particularly in Queensland, in the later months of last year. What happened, as I recall it, is that we had an investigation of the growth of the use of nitrogen, basically, and we received advice. I will check this but I believe that advice was from some representatives of the College of Dermatologists and also from a Medicare advisory committee. I will have to check which committee gave us the advice. I do not remember that right now.

PARA.TAB: There certainly was a concern that there had been a growth in this kind of work which had not always had the desired effect, so when that decision was made it was made on advice from the profession. I am happy to provide that information for Senator Herron—I was going to say at the end of question time, but that will probably be pretty soon, so I will not be able to do it today—at the first available opportunity early next week.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. I refer the minister to the failure of the New South Wales and Victorian governments to sign the national child-care strategy. What steps is the federal government taking to ensure that families in these states do not miss out on the allocation of child-care places?

—I thank Senator West for her question. It is very interesting that despite ongoing negotiations between the Commonwealth and New South Wales and Victoria, both New South Wales and Victoria have failed to sign the national child-care strategy. Indeed, last December the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Fahey, advised that the New South Wales government was `actively considering its position on this matter'. I do not know what people mean by active consideration, but New South Wales has been doing that since 1990, along with Victoria—they say they will, they say they won't, but they still haven't. All I can say is that I have heard very little serious talk from either of these state governments about their intention to sign with the Commonwealth the national child-care strategy.

PARA.TAB: It is quite clear that both of those states do not have much regard for the needs of working families and their need for child care. However, the Commonwealth government is very concerned about that and it is very determined that families in Victoria and New South Wales do not miss out. Because of that concern, we have delivered on a promise made by the Prime Minister during the last election that we would, if necessary, enter into direct partnerships with both local governments and community organisations and bypass the states to ensure that the parents in both of those states have access to ongoing child-care places.

I am very pleased to tell the Senate today that our pilot program to establish 500 places in New South Wales and Victoria under these direct partnerships has been a success. Earlier this year I announced that we have finalised arrangements to establish 280 new long day care places in New South Wales and 221 new places in Victoria through these direct partnerships. In addition, over the same time, because of the failure of these two states to enter into an agreement, we have decided to provide 7,000 fully Commonwealth funded, outside school hours care places in both New South Wales and Victoria. I am also pleased to advise that to this point we are well on the way to meeting that target, with over 4,000 places now approved.

I suspect all senators here have heard from their local community groups about the need for outside school hours places. They can assure their constituents in New South Wales and Victoria that it is the Commonwealth government that is making sure they get them, in the face of those two states simply refusing over more than four years now to be prepared to enter into an agreement. I hope that all senators, in the light of their constituents' requests, will assist in applying pressure to the states to make sure that they fulfil their obligations to families in their own states.

This is the International Year of the Family. Child care is an ongoing and critical issue for all families. Victoria and New South Wales cannot go on hiding behind their failure to deliver on a serious commitment to child care by failing to sign with the Commonwealth the national child-care strategy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to move a motion to take note of your intervention during question time.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement made by the President during question time relating to privilege resolution No. 9 of 25 February 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, your intervention was unprecedented. Certainly in my experience in the nearly 13 years I have been in this place an incident has not occurred in which a President has stood during question time, without invitation in the form of a point of order being taken, to read to the Senate part of a resolution that it had previously carried in relation to privileges and, in effect, to warn the Senate to ensure that in asking questions a reference is not made that might include an allegation against someone.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, it seems to me that resolution 9 of that particular resolution that you referred to is, as was stated by one of my colleagues, clearly included to protect third parties. It does not seem to me that it has anything to do with the rights and security of a senator in this place or a member in the other place whose rights are clearly protected by standing order 193(3). In other words, Mr President, if an unfair reflection is being made upon a senator or member, you clearly have a right under that standing order to protect that member.

Resolution 9 relates to an entirely different matter, and that is to ensure that when speaking in the Senate or in committee senators do not unfairly refer to third parties, which are unable to respond. The final words are included for good and sensible reasons. If that interpretation is correct, one must wonder why you raised it in the middle of question time immediately following a question by Senator Baume referring to the Prime Minister. One can only fairly presume that you were in fact warning members of the opposition that they should not be asking questions of the nature of that asked by Senator Baume in relation to the Prime Minister.

What did Senator Baume ask in relation to the Prime Minister? He said that there is evidence from ASC documentation to suggest that the Prime Minister, through his business interests, is indebted to Mr Brown, a former member of parliament and a current lobbyist, for a sum of money that could be in the area of millions of dollars. He raised the issue of a potential conflict of interest arising out of being so indebted to a lobbyist.

I could not think of any more legitimate question for a member of parliament to ask. Surely a potential conflict of interest must arise with the Prime Minister taking on such an enormous and complex business interest at a time when he is Prime Minister. I understand that he took it on when he was Treasurer, but he advanced it when he was on the back bench in the form of reaching agreement with the Danes and carrying on the detailed running of the negotiations. He now says that he is at arms-length.

But there must be a potential conflict of interest in every direction; whether it relates to the loans from the Commonwealth Bank, of which the Commonwealth, as a shareholder, has a major interest; whether it relates to relations with the Danes because the Danes are a party to this business; whether it relates to debts to lobbyists who were former members of parliament; whether it relates to the importation of semen; or whether it relates to the AQIS matters that were raised during the last parliament. All these are areas of potential conflict of interest that arise out of a Prime Minister of this country having the sort of business interests that Mr Keating has decided to embark upon.

It is quite legitimate, I put to you, Mr President, for us to raise those issues in this place and question the minister representing the Prime Minister, Senator Gareth Evans, as to the extent of those potential conflicts of interest. It is legitimate for us to ask whether Mr Keating has in fact made full disclosure in the cabinet room, and matters of that nature. I put it to you, Mr President, that that is not only a legitimate thing to do, but it is our responsibility to do it.

Therefore, to be warned, in effect, in those circumstances that we should not be asking questions of this nature causes those of us on this side of the chamber great concern. I ask you in the course of this debate to explain why you chose, immediately after Senator Baume's question, to raise this particular resolution of the Senate. What were you seeking to communicate? What warning were you seeking to give to us? In informing us of that, I ask you to reflect upon what I have just put to you. I invite you to recognise that this resolution relates to something entirely different from what you were referring to, and that there is a relevant standing order that enables you to protect the Prime Minister from an unfair reflection. But it is not an unfair reflection when we raise matters—matters that are already on the public record—that perhaps contain obvious areas of both conflict of interest and potential conflict of interest.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, as I noted down what you said, you referred to the increasing practice of making unsubstantiated allegations against ministers, senators and others in this place. Your reference was not only to ministers of the crown—
—Do you always take notes of what he says?
—There it is. It is written down at the bottom of this particular sheet of—
—You always take notes of what he says, do you? Every time he opens his mouth, you write it down?

—When it seems to be potentially relevant to something I have been involved in. Mr President, as I wrote it down you said, `the increasing practice of making unsubstantiated allegations against ministers, senators and others'.
—I'll watch you next time.
—Senator Patterson should do that; she would be interested.
—Did you put him up to it?

—No; on the contrary. Mr President, what I understood you to be doing, in referring to standing order No. 9 on page 101 about the exercise of freedom of speech, was drawing attention to what has perhaps been an under-recognised and under-remembered provision of our standing orders concerning imputations, innuendos or smears against people outside the parliament. TALK.START.PARA: —It was all documented over a year ago.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I suggest that you are absolutely within your rights as the President of this place to draw attention to these matters at your own discretion, in your own way and in your own time when you regard it as appropriate to do so, to draw attention to the misuse or potential misuse of the forms and privileges of this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I also wish to speak with respect to, as described by Senator Hill, your unprecedented intervention in question time today. PARA.TAB: I put to you, Mr President, one other option available to you that has been taken by other presidents in the past when they thought someone had in one way or another been transgressing the standing orders or bringing this place into some form of disrepute; that is, a quiet phone call to say, `Would you like to come around and have a cup of tea?'. I say to you that if you believe that someone or a group of people are in some way not doing the right thing, the appropriate course for you to choose in the future—if I may respectfully suggest—is not to make such a public intervention. We have not seen happen here, and we do not want to see happen here, the President of this chamber—either substantively or giving the appearance of—taking instructions from the table, especially if it is from the side the President happened to come from before he took up that position. That is all very unfortunate for you, and on that basis I suggest that should you wish to direct senators' attention to particular remarks in the future, you would do not only this place but yourself as well a great service if you did so privately.

Last but not least, I want to raise the question of unsubstantiated allegations and the raising thereof. Senator Evans has sought time and time again basically to put the argument that, if senators raise an substantiated allegation, they must be doing so in bad faith, they must be doing so simply to make a political point and there must be nothing in the allegation. He somehow seems to give the impression that he already knows the answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Brian Burke.

—Senator Patterson interjects, `Brian Burke'—we saw an example of this in that case. The very point about an allegation is that it is just that. It is not a completely made out case. One of the very important points and advantages of parliamentary privilege is that people out there—taxpayers who cannot afford to raise an allegation and find out that they are wrong; they are too frightened to do so because of what the bureaucracy will do to them if they do—can come to senators and honourable members with an allegation. I accept that some allegations are made in bad faith but, by and large, people come in good faith because they believe there is a problem.

PARA.TAB: It is the job of people in this place to look at those allegations and get answers to them. By raising those questions, one either disposes of the allegation—in which case, the person about whom it is made is exonerated and completely satisfied; presumably, such people would not be worried about their affairs being raised—or, of course, one substantiates the allegation. I conclude by making the point that it is a nonsense to suggest that people can ask questions in here only when they know the answers to them. It would make this whole place completely unworthwhile. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have to say to you directly that I object to the remarks you made. I find it absolutely disgraceful that you should make them in the context of my question. I refer to the remarks about unsubstantiated allegations. You made those remarks in the context of a question which did not contain unsubstantiated allegations. However, they were so described by Senator Gareth Evans. Immediately after he had so described them, you made a statement saying effectively that unsubstantiated allegations should not be made in this chamber. I do not know who is scripting whom, but I find it absolutely offensive that you should accept, apparently, Senator Evans's version of these as unsubstantiated allegations as in fact a matter with which to chide me, because the context could only involve that inference.

PARA.TAB: It seems, Mr President, from your prepared statement, that you made up your mind to hit a six off the next ball. It happens to have been the wrong ball. The fact is that my question—I will repeat it for your benefit—was: are the Australian people entitled to know the size of the financial obligation Mr Keating's half-owned companies owe to John Brown, his former ministerial colleague who has lobbied this government on behalf of various interest groups and has been a government appointee to official positions? In view of the four different versions of the debt to John Brown revealed in the Prime Minister's piggery group's chaotic accounts, ranging from the $4.5 million to nothing, will you tell the Australian people how much their Prime Minister's companies really owe Mr Brown?

What are the unsubstantiated allegations?—because that is how you characterised them in the context of your remarks. Your remarks immediately followed my statements of fact. Senator Evans said, `But they are not facts; we have never seen them'. We have gone to immense trouble in this chamber to present these facts, the reasons being that the government refused to do so, that Mr Keating refused to do so, that his companies have consistently failed to meet the requirements of the law and the Securities Commission. The only reason these facts are available is my continual protests in this chamber and the letter I wrote to the Securities Commission requiring it to take note of the fact that the law had been blatantly breached by Mr Keating's piggery companies.

Let us get the position clear. In early 1992—that is, some seven or eight months after Mr Keating became an owner of this group—his company put in a return for the year 1990 when he was not an owner. It eventually put in a return which showed nothing about this kind of debt; it showed nothing about the details of the accounts. It was grossly inadequate, and as a result the Securities Commission required the company to come out with more detailed material. Eventually the company did, and that detailed material showed a debt—a liability—to Brown and Hatton, as it is called, Mr Brown's company, of $4.5 million. Senator Evans says that he has never seen it, that he does not know anything about it.

With your permission, Mr President, when I have been able to return to my office I shall bring that annual return here. Rather than simply table the returns, I will also seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the sections dealing with the indebtedness. I will present the four different versions of that indebtedness which appeared in the three subsequent returns that had to be put in because of the falsity of the returns that had been put in to the ASC. Those false returns had to be corrected. Those false returns massively understated the huge losses of those companies.

I am dealing with facts. The facts are that there were four different versions, in the accounts that were reluctantly produced by Mr Keating's companies, of how much Mr Brown was owed. By good luck, I happen to have two of them with me. The annual return for the year 30 June 1990—the unaudited return, which is breaking the law—when in fact those companies were public companies for nine-tenths of the year, as I recall, said this in version No. 2 or No. 3, I cannot remember:

SPEECH.PARA: The company has not recorded in its financial statements a potential liability of $4 million—

I do not know what happened to the other $500,000. Five hundred thousand dollars does not mean much to prime ministers. They can find $430,000 out of nowhere to buy a half interest in a piggery company, so I suppose why worry about $500,000?
. . . a potential liability of $4 million relating to the purchase price associated with the acquisition of the wholesale pig business and associated naming rights of Brown and Hatton Pty Ltd.
Is the Australian Labor Party disputing the figure of $4 million?
The $4 million will only be paid if the company's directors so determine and if the company makes sufficient profits and has sufficient funds available to pay the additional price of $4 million.
If I recall, that one was signed by Mr Constantinidis, but I can check that later. It was, of course, unaudited. Another return says:

The subordinated loans recorded in the company's balance sheet under shareholders' equity have been determined by reference to the amount due to the previous owners of the business undertakings associated with Brown and Hatton Group Ltd. As subordinated loans, such amounts will be reduced commensurately subject to the future profitability of the company and the availability of cash resources.
In fact, they were the audited 1991 parent company accounts filed with the Securities Commission. These are not unsubstantiated allegations. These are documents filed with the Securities Commission.

PARA.TAB: Now what are the subordinated loans? They were listed as $3.38 million in 1990 and $2.76 million in 1991. That is why I asked which is the right amount that is really owed. Have these figures just been written down in the books because provisions have been made against them, or has the amount owed to Mr Brown been diminished because some payments have been made?

When I ask whether the Australian people are entitled to know the size of the debt that Mr Keating owes to Mr Brown, the size of the debt itself obviously is a matter of some substance. I have asked various leading accountants about the extraordinary manner in which this debt to Mr Brown has been handled. Even in the latest accounts that are available, where it is regarded as a subordinated loan and therefore a part of shareholder's equity, I have come across the universal view that the reclassification of the debt to equity was not only controversial but also wrong in principle. Paragraph 29 of the appendix giving guidance to people who put in annual returns says, under the statement of accounting concepts:

SPEECH.PARA: In practice, subordinated loans have sometimes been classified as equity. However, the fact that a loan is subordinated, that is, given a lower ranking for repayment than some or all other debts of the entity, does not change the essential nature of these securities. Subordinated loans possess the essential characteristics of liabilities and should be recognised as such in the statement of financial position.

I was obviously clearly entitled to ask: what is the real debt owing to John Brown if it is in the public interest to know by how much a Prime Minister is obligated—protected by the corporate veil—to a lobbyist and an appointee to various government boards? My leader, Senator Hill, said, `If that is not a proper question, then I find it very difficult to understand what a proper question is'. If it is the sort of question that prompts and deserves the sort of response you gave it, Mr President, then I strongly disagree with your judgment on this matter.

PARA.TAB: The other point I would like to make is that the Prime Minister by his inaction did nothing to correct those grievous errors in his group's accounts which I kept pointing out here, and which were dismissed by those opposite, and by the Prime Minister himself, as unsubstantiated muckraking. I repeat that: these facts have non-stop been described as unsubstantiated muckraking. I suppose I should be pleased, Mr President, that you only described them as unsubstantiated allegations. At least you have not got that part of the script correct.

The Prime Minister's companies were only obliged to put in their correct returns after I wrote to the Securities Commission and the Securities Commission had an investigation which resulted in those false returns being corrected by the companies. But not by the company's own initiative, despite my repeated statements here—all described, as I said, as unsubstantiated muckraking—which were proven to be absolutely correct.

When the Prime Minister half owns a company which fails to report that it owes $4.5 million to Mr John Brown, people can make whatever inference they like. I was simply seeking to know the facts. If I had wanted to make inferences I could have said: why is the Prime Minister hiding the fact that his company owes John Brown $4.5 million and that he is the half owner of the company that owes John Brown that money? As it was, we saw the Prime Minister not correcting the false impression created by a false return to the Securities Commission that his investment in this group was $43,000. That was an official document lodged with the Securities Commission.

It was reported in the newspapers that the Prime Minister had made an investment of $43,000. When I eventually sought the corrected versions, the Securities Commission documents revealed that it was $430,000—just a slight typographical error—in the same way as the returns consistently failed to reveal that losses of hundreds of thousands of dollars were in fact losses because they were put there as profits. Mr President, I can say to you, that we simply wanted—and I simply wanted in asking that question—to know the extent to which the Prime Minister, through his half owned company, was under some obligation to another Australian. It does not seem that Senator Evans's suggestion that I was somehow blackguarding John Brown in this matter stands up. I was asking for the facts. I was asking whether it was sensible for a Prime Minister to be under a multimillion dollar obligation to a lobbyist and government appointee in this way.

I have in the meantime, I hope, been given the annual returns. I would hope to be able to seek leave to incorporate in Hansard those sections of the annual returns which reveal the different manner in which this debt to John Brown has either been covered up or hidden. I believe that this chamber has the right to ask for that sort of information. We never expect to get an answer, but we have a right to ask. One would hope that the media would be interested in the fact that we never get an answer—that when we ask questions that are right and proper, we do not get answers. There was no answer to this one. There will be no answer to the right and proper questions—and I suggest, Mr President, that you might like to look at the others that I have asked since parliament resumed this year—that I have asked about the piggery matter.

Where there is a potential conflict of interest, it is crucial to the issue that there should be full information. Information is the heart of the matter. We heard today, for example, the absolute nonsense of Senator Evans saying, `If we had the same sort of reporting standards that are required in the House of Representatives, we would see a few things'. This has demonstrated that the House of Representatives and ministerial reporting standards are so inadequate, hopeless and capable of being got around by a cunning operative that, when the Prime Minister made his declaration of interest, when he said that he had bought an interest in a company which had an interest in a piggery, we had no idea that in fact he had bought the half ownership of a company which totally owned a piggery group. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I think the reason why we are taking this matter to the extent that we are is that we view it very seriously indeed. Certainly, at the outset of your presidency, I think it is fundamentally important that we all understand the ground rules.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cooney made a great point of saying that you were elected unanimously. I have to say that all of what has taken place today can lead to only one conclusion, and that is, that it was your intention before you came into this chamber to make the statement you did the next time that Senator Baume asked a question relating to the Prime Minister's financial interest. The circumstantial evidence is overwhelming.

Otherwise, we would not have had the slightest idea of what you were talking about. You spoke about `unsubstantiated allegations'; that term is not used in resolution 9 under `Exercise of Freedom of Speech'. The term `unsubstantiated' is one you chose to use on the back of what Senator Evans had to say in this matter, and follows a repeated assertion of that characterisation by Senator Evans in response to a number of questions from Senator Baume. You could only have been intending to refer to this issue, and this you saw as the perfect opportunity to jump in and make your views known.

It is one thing to warn people in the abstract about thinking before they make allegations, but to intervene in the way that you did and to use that term `unsubstantiated' is highly judgmental. You were effectively passing judgment. What is critical to remember is that halfway through that fulmination Senator Evans said, `I don't know the facts of this matter'. He then proceeded to tell us his strategy. His strategy is that because he alleges that Senator Baume has got it wrong in the past—which, of course, none of us concedes in any shape or form; he has done a very thorough and diligent job based on a lot of careful research but, nonetheless, Senator Evans has chosen that tactic—therefore, Senator Evans is not going to answer the question. That has been the political approach of the government on a number of occasions. To simply ask a question does not constitute unsubstantiated allegations. `Unsubstantiated' means that someone has ruled on the merits. Someone has looked at these allegations and found that they do not stack up. The last thing those opposite ought to be doing is passing judgement in that way. It is certainly not for them to characterise these as unsubstantiated allegations.

Therefore, Mr President, your intervention was highly unfortunate. To the extent that it was intended to fire a warning shot across our bows, I can say that we will not be deterred. Indeed, if your intention was to try to up the ante, as it were, then you are effectively trying to plunge a dagger into the heart of one of the most cherished of democratic principles, and that is, freedom of speech.

This place is all about asking questions and, quite often, getting non-responsive answers. That is what the game is often about. Senators do not want to come in here and raise matters without any foundation for the very good reason that it backfires on them, they lose credibility, they do not prove their point and they are simply not taken seriously in the future. There is a very real built-in restraint to so-called unsubstantiated allegations in this chamber.

One can only inevitably conclude that you, Mr President, were trying to suggest that in this particular matter it is not appropriate for us to canvass issues of conflict of interest on the part of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister would have to be one of the world's greatest bullies. He is one of the people who has almost unlimited opportunities to defend himself through all manners of procedures of this chamber. It was then suggested that somehow there is a relevance to resolution 9 to protect those persons who might have limited opportunities to respond and to have regard to the rights of others. The Prime Minister is in an unparalleled position to defend himself and to provide responsive answers if there are indeed answers to be made to Senator Baume's allegations.

In those circumstances, Mr President, you ought to reflect very carefully. We do not stand here alleging any general lack of confidence in you. We very much want to see you get it right, and to get it right as often as is humanly possible. What we do not want, and what we have not had in this chamber in the eight years I have been here, is a President who is clearly one sided. I regret to say that is not the public perception of what goes on in the House of Representatives, but certainly we believe that your two predecessors in this chamber, Doug McClelland and Kerry Sibraa, acted with commendable impartiality, did not seek to intervene improperly and understood how we make this place function. When the government does not have the numbers, this place is potentially very unruly. That is why it is critically important that the President exercise a moderating influence, not an inflammatory one.

Secondly, I made the point that in the early months of the Labor government in 1983 we saw that the Reserve Bank was unable to conduct proper monetary policy within the confines of a fixed exchange rate. In March 1983 the government devalued the dollar by 10 per cent. By the second week in December the dollar was virtually driven to its original level by large capital inflows.

My point was a very simple one: that Mr Keating should have followed the advice given to the government in the months prior to December 1983, in either September or October, by the likes of Ross Garnaut, Ted Evans and others, and floated the dollar instead of delaying the decision until a currency crisis developed in 1983. SPEECH.PARA: We didn't make a formal decision to float until the death knock.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Short's motion in which he draws the Senate's attention to the attacks that the Keating Government has made on a number of important Australian national symbols and significant institutions. In times of crisis symbols such as the flag can become important rallying points.

PARA.TAB: Symbols, therefore, acquire a deep meaning and can arouse considerable emotion. Who could not have been moved when, some 12 months ago, the Vietnam veterans marched in the streets and 512 flags were carried by those old soldiers? Who could not have been moved to see the Australian flag being the symbol of their feelings towards their nation and their commemoration of their colleagues?

This, not surprisingly, can lead to widespread bitterness and division.

I think it is true to say that the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, has made a habit of savagely attacking many of the cherished national symbols and institutions of this country. I believe that this attack is not based on nationalistic sentiment, but on his detestation of many aspects of Australia's history and life.

We have only to look at the current list of symbols that are coming under sustained attack from this government. Of course, the flag is regularly in the firing line. The Constitution is also in the firing line. Mr Free's office attacked the Australian flag—our flag for more than 90 years—as being British derived.

Senator Short raises the question of the oath in his motion. We are arguably the world's oldest democracy. The liberties of this country have flourished; Australian citizens have grown in prosperity; and the great Australian values of tolerance and equity have also grown over the last 90 years within this system. Mr Keating and his colleagues will find it difficult to bring in this republic. But I believe there is something strange going on here. I would like to focus on an institution in this nation that I and so many Australians cherish. I refer to the magnificent role of the Christian churches in Australian society. There is no doubt that so many Australian values reflect the western tradition and the Christian values which have been passed down from our forebears. Most Australians describe themselves in public opinion polls as Christian. I, like many Australians, went to the Remembrance Day service on 11 November for the committal of the unknown soldier. It was a very moving service, and there would be few Australians who did not feel a surge of emotion on that day. The mounted horse helping to escort the coffin, and the soldiers and women in the service dress of the First World War, painted a very dramatic, emotional picture.

In my understanding of the military traditions, Christian services are very common, and even when the denomination of a soldier is not known, he is given a Christian burial. TALK.START.PARA: —In Senator Faulkner's letter, I draw attention to these words:

I am comfortable with a multicultural society. My wife is French, of Jewish origin, and I profess the Christian faith. It would have been interesting if Senator Crowley in her guidelines had said, `Ensure that where children of the Christian faith are in the centres Christmas carols are played'. I would like Senator Faulkner to look again at the letter he sent me and at the motion that was passed. It is possible he was not aware of that motion, and I accept that. I would have no evidence that the government gave this ruling or influenced this decision, but I would like Senator Faulkner's—

I am one who is very proud of this country. I regard myself as a nationalist. I regard myself as someone who treasures the achievements of this country and recognises Australia for its great virtues. But I am also one who is getting a little fed up by this government's constant attack on the institutions in this country. It is with great pleasure that I support Senator Short's motion. It is an important one, and I look forward to hearing some response from a Labor member of parliament. If Senator Faulkner is listening, I ask him to come into the chamber to explain precisely why that decision was made.
