TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to speak on Senator Short's motion. I do not support Senator Short in respect of most of the sentiments that are expressed in his motion. In fact, I wish to put on record the Australian Democrats' support for the new oath of allegiance, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: From this time forward, under God,
I pledge my loyalty to Australia and its people,
whose democratic beliefs I share,
whose rights and liberties I respect, and
whose laws I will uphold and obey.

I believe that this oath of allegiance and its companion affirmation of allegiance is a noble statement. The Democrats supported it when it was passed by this chamber. I believe that Senator Short's expression of regret that it was not going to be reviewed yet again in the review of the Australian Citizenship Act is misplaced. The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs examined all the issues. Senator Short was present at most of the public hearings. We have had a good debate on this issue.

PARA.TAB: I believe we should now move ahead. That is the basic sentiment that I would like to express. We should not get stuck in the past; we should not be held back by our history. I think our history is important; it is part of our culture. Our symbols are important. But with an oath of allegiance that we ask new citizens to this country to take, we should not be sidetracked by suggesting that they should pledge allegiance to a constitutional form. It should be to the substance; it should be to this country—to Australia.

In contrast to most honourable senators who were lucky enough to be born in this country, I express those sentiments as one who chose to come to this country and to become a citizen of Australia and take this oath of allegiance—not in its current form; in its previous form. It was in 1952 that I took the oath of allegiance, some 2 1/2 years after I came to this country and decided that I wanted to make it my country, that I wanted it to be the country where I raised my family, where I wanted to be a loyal citizen and where I wanted my children to be citizens. I found it somewhat irrational that I was asked to swear allegiance to a queen who was not a part of this country's everyday life. I believe that we must now recognise that the Queen will not be part of this country's future, certainly not as its monarch.

Therefore, I think that it is time we left historical relics behind us and moved ahead. It is time we thought about the future of this country in its substance and adjusted the symbols and the forms we are using to that substance. I express no view on what our flag should be. In fact, the Democrats are on record as saying that the flag should not be changed unless we have a referendum or a plebiscite of some sort so that the citizens of Australia can express a view and make their choice.

As I said, the Australian Democrats supported the introduction of this new pledge. I was able to get the government to accept some amendments to the preamble which emphasised the obligations of citizenship as well as the rights. Also, the minister agreed to my suggestion that the preamble should be read out at each citizenship ceremony and that the certificates that citizens receive should include not only the oath of allegiance but also the preamble which I believe, in very clear and poetic words, expresses the rights and obligations of Australian citizenship which we all treasure.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in supporting the motion before the chair moved by Senator Short condemning the government for its divisive approach to Australia's national symbols. I would like to deal briefly with the contribution we have just had from Senator Spindler of the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: I have always had the view that senators were entitled to speak their minds in this place, and I do not criticise Senator Spindler for having views that are different from my own. But there are two points I want to comment on. The first one is his claim that Australia in some way is held back by our history. Nothing could be further from the truth. In this country we have an enormous amount to be proud of. Our achievements in national development, I believe, stand second to no other country. Yet we hear from Senator Spindler that Australia should not be held back by our history.

We should be proud of our history and, as the current generation, we should seek to emulate the achievements of the past. I can understand that Senator Spindler has a biased view of history if he takes his view of it from what appears on the ABC, and all those bowdlerised versions of docudramas where those in the new class write what they imagine happened in the past and interpret Australia through false sociological eyes. I can understand it if he listens to or reads the works of people like Manning Clark.

But that is not what Australia is about. Australia does have a very proud history, and that history was one of achievement. I am very distressed that Australia has changed in my lifetime from a `can do' society where people went off and did things for themselves and for the benefit of the community, into a society nurtured by the ALP, the Democrats and similar fringe groups where the belief is taught to kids in school that they have to rely on the government if they want anything done for them. If they want it done honestly, ethically, ecologically correct or politically correct, get the government to do it—the negation of the ability of the individual—and it was through the individual that this nation was built.

It is also sad that Senator Spindler does not understand the legal and constitutional basis on which this country was founded. I do not intend to embark upon a lecture on constitutional law for Senator Spindler because I do not wish to spend the time.

One of our great national symbols that I want to talk about for a few minutes is the veterans of this country. Senator Kemp spoke about the ceremony on Remembrance Day last year when the tomb of the unknown Australian soldier was consecrated at the War Memorial. We owe a great deal to the veterans of this country. They are one of our great national symbols. When this country went to war in 1914 the government of the day made certain promises to those who enlisted. One promise was, `We will look after you if you are injured and, if you are killed, we will look after your descendants'. In that was the genesis of the first of the repatriation acts which, in the 80-odd years since the first bill was passed, have been developed and expanded into a very comprehensive service, currently administered under the Veterans' Entitlements Act.

It is proper that we honour and respect not only the letter of the law but also the spirit of the promise that the country made to those veterans at the time. Those people volunteered to lay down their lives for their country. They could not possibly have made a bigger sacrifice than that. Of course, their successors today are the members of the Australian Defence Force, the men and women who wear the uniform of this country.

Despite the views of the government and various other people, they are not just Australian citizens doing a job that is a branch of the Public Service; they are special people filling a unique role. Their uniqueness comes from the fact that they literally die on orders. No member of the Public Service, least of all any member of this parliament, dies on orders when his leader tells him to do that. So they deserve a special place in the consciousness of this country. I would argue that veterans are very much part of Australian history and Australian culture, and it is up to this parliament to honour the undertakings that it made in years past.

A point of great concern to me was the answer that Senator Faulkner gave at question time today to a question I asked yesterday as to how many veterans have had their service or disability pension suspended or cancelled for failure to provide a tax file number. He came back today with the answer that there were 125 veterans.

I do not know the details of all those 125 veterans who have had their pensions cancelled or withdrawn for not providing a tax file number, but I do know some of them, and I know one in particular. In that case I find it absolutely indefensible that the Department of Veterans' Affairs has withdrawn that person's pension. Even if there is only one case where there has been an unjust action, it is one case too many.

As part of the compensation payments for war service, governments of all persuasions in Australia have instituted two pensions for veterans. One is the service pension, which is similar to, and in many ways exactly the same as, the age pension. The only difference is that it is paid five years earlier, at age 60, to a veteran, instead of age 65, in compensation for the reduction in his or her earning capacity through life as a consequence of war service. Like the age pension, it is income and assets tested.

There is another pension known as the disability pension. This is paid in compensation for a reduction in the ability of veterans to live a normal life. They may be damaged psychologically or physically. They might have arthritis or have lost a limb or several limbs. They might be crippled to any degree. A disability pension is paid to veterans as compensation for the physical or mental limitation in enjoying life as a consequence of their war service. Because of that, it is different from the service pension, and it is not income or assets tested. It needs no imagination to see that there is a difference between these two pensions.

I turn to the tax file number. The tax file number legislation was passed through this parliament with the primary purpose of preventing fraud and preventing people making unjustified or multiple claims against the Commonwealth for pensions or benefits of some sort, or rewards in some way or other. It was also introduced to make sure that people paid their taxes. In essence, it was designed to prevent fraud. How can we have fraud in relation to a disability pension? How is it possible to measure someone's physical or mental disabilities and equate that with fraud? Remember, these disabilities come from war service and the fact that someone cannot enjoy life the way we can. A disability pension is paid, since it is not means tested, not only to paupers but also to millionaires. It is even paid to criminals in jail. A service pension is not paid to those in jail, nor am I aware of any other pension being paid. But a disability pension, because of the reason for its existence, is paid to rich and poor alike, irrespective of whether someone is in jail, convicted of fraud, or anything else.

The case in question that I am very concerned about is that of an Australian veteran who served 5 1/2 years in the Second World War. He saw active service and had an outstanding war record. He was severely and permanently injured as a consequence of that—

Unlike Senator MacGibbon, I did not hear Senator Spindler say words to the effect that Australia had been held back by our history. Aboriginals are certainly individuals in this nation, but I do not think they were particularly part of it when it was being built.

SPEECH.PARA: I swear by Almighty God that I will be faithful and bear true allegiance to Her Majesty Elizabeth the Second, Queen of Australia, Her heirs and successors according to law, and that I will faithfully observe the laws of Australia and fulfil my duties as an Australian Citizen.

PARA.TAB: Interestingly, whenever this government tackles what can be described as difficult issues, the opposition alleges the government is divisive. We could make the same accusation of the opposition in respect of Fightback. The opposition might argue that Fightback had substantial community support, and it did—it did not have majority community support as it turned out—but it was certainly divisive. But we did not advance that argument against Fightback. We fought Fightback on what we saw as the merits of the argument. The opposition certainly disagreed with our views and the Australian public cast its decision at the last election.

We do not go around with this trite nonsense about things being divisive. Really, the opposition will have to grow up because elections are determined by 50 per cent plus one. Elections are determined by governments being seen to tackle issues in a genuine and honest way—not by this nonsense about being divisive. If those opposite want to continue to kid themselves by branding the government's determination to tackle issues as divisive, it will not help them when it comes to the next election—it did not help them in the last one.
The new oath and affirmation of allegiance was referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. The committee received 20 submissions and held a number of public hearings.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was after the bill had been introduced.

PARA.TAB: The simple reason that why it was done last year by the government is that it is its agenda to institute a republic in this country. The net result of what the government has done has been to create yet another major division within Australian communities and society. The reason the coalition has moved its motion—we are about to end the debate on it—is that whether or not the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his government like it, a nation's symbols and institutions are of fundamental importance to its stability, good government and sovereign independence; and the well-being of its people.

To make changes to the basic institutions and symbols requires very careful, evolutionary, fully consultative, inclusive consideration. This government, time and again, has pursued policies of exclusion. A small group of people basically within the cabal of government is making decisions and foisting them on the Australian people, hoping it will be able to prevent division. It runs the risk of rendering asunder the stability and good order of this government.

The approach of the coalition is not, as Senator Sherry and other honourable senators opposite would have us believe, reactionary. It is a very positive and progressive approach. Our symbols and institutions are of fundamental importance to our society, to good governance and to the independence of our nation. It is absolutely hypocritical for the government and the Prime Minister in particular to be running around talking about a lack of independence on Australia's part, when at the same time they are instituting economic and social policies that strike very much at the core of that independence.

So for those reasons—and I will not reiterate all the additional reasons—we have been prompted to move this motion. Senator Kemp spoke so eloquently on it today. Senator MacGibbon stretched his licence a bit, but he raised some very important issues. I congratulate him on his initiative and creativity in bringing them in as part of the debate.

We should all ponder and consider very closely Senator Kemp's contribution in relation to the prayers that were offered at the service for remembrance of the unknown soldier last year because our society is still fundamentally and overwhelmingly Christian; we are a Judaeo-Christian nation. To delete all reference to the Judaeo-Christian concept that underpins so much of our nation, despite the changes that are occurring, is a very, corrosive element and runs some very severe risks in the way it is done.

I hope very much that the Australian Democrats and the Greens will also support the motion before the chair. I do not hold my breath on that, but I do urge those who think very seriously about Australia's national symbols and institutions to look very carefully, when they vote, at what this motion is seeking to do. I have high hopes that, if they think about that carefully and sensibly, the motion will be passed.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Short's) be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Campbell, I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

(a)condemns the disgraceful intervention in land management decisions by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) when, on 4 February 1994, he issued an order that will halt the development of a crocodile farm at Broome in Western Australia, that development having undergone no less than 4 years of environmental, local government and aboriginal heritage approval processes and having the support of local aboriginal groups who would specifically benefit from the employment opportunities;
(b)calls on the Minister to immediately withdraw his order and leave land use decisions to State and local authorities and the communities they serve; and

(c)expresses its fear that the Minister's actions are but a first taste of the Federal Government's intentions to use their national land rights scheme to destroy economic development in Western Australia at the cost of the living standards and opportunities for aborigines living in remote areas.

SPEECH.PARA: I think at the outset it is worthwhile to look at the history of this matter, which is quite involved. In July 1987, a gentleman by the name of Malcolm Douglas expressed an interest in the lease for a crocodile farm in Broome. The venture was to process the crocodile meat and skins for export as well as to provide a tourist attraction. Furthermore, there was also to be a facility for research into crocodiles and a facility to accommodate any rogue animals.

PARA.TAB: In that area and in the northern parts generally of Australia from time to time there has been trouble with crocodiles that have attacked human beings—in fact killed them on the odd occasions. The policy is not to shoot them but to find some sort of refuge for them. This venture was to provide such a refuge for crocodiles.

At that time, the Yawuru Aboriginal Corporation had not been formed. Notwithstanding this, Malcolm Douglas made contact with local Aborigines, whom he knew. I think it is worthwhile to note that Mr Douglas himself has spent a good deal of time in the north of Australia and has been involved with the crocodile industry for the last 10 years. Mr Douglas has spent most of his life living with Aboriginal people and one of his best friends is a tribal elder. In fact, Mr Douglas has made films about Aboriginal culture, which are now in the national archives in Canberra. He is a gentleman who is well versed in living in the north of this country and well associated with Aboriginal people.

In any event, in 1987 Mr Douglas expressed an interest in the lease and, during the ensuing two years, there were extended negotiations with local government and local Aborigines. At that stage the Yawuru Aboriginal Corporation had not been formed.

In 1990, discussions were engaged with the Environmental Protection Authority and a site inspection took place with shire councillors and tribal elders. In fact, Paddy Roe, a spokesman for the local Aboriginal group, attended the inspection and went around the property with Mr Douglas. He indicated that at that time he could not see any problems at all in relation to sacred sites. Discussions and negotiations continued.

In 1991 a consultative environmental review took place. At that stage, the chairman of the Yawuru Aboriginal Corporation gave his consent to the proposed venture. The corporation had in the meantime been formed and his consent was given to the venture on the basis that the Yawuru people be consulted from time to time.

In June 1992 an agreement was signed between the chairperson of the Yawuru Aboriginal Corporation and Mr Douglas for the development of a crocodile farm. At the time, the Labor government gave its consent to the development on the basis that there be consent forthcoming from the corporation. At that time, the minister responsible for museum sites issued a section 18 certificate under the appropriate legislation. In 1992, the consultative environmental report was released and the matter proceeded.

At that stage, Mr Douglas could be forgiven for thinking that the development of his crocodile farm was well on its way and there was no impediment to its development. At that stage he could well be forgiven for thinking that there was no opposition to it in an environmental sense or from local Aborigines. But in December 1992 the Kimberley Land Council commissioned a report from a Canadian to assess the matter. He maintained that there was a sacred site involved and there was a reconsideration of the matter. As a result of that, the consent of the minister was revoked. That was just prior to the state election early last year.

After further negotiations and consultations with the various departments, in July 1993 the consent was granted by the new Liberal government of Western Australia. That consent was granted on the basis that a certain area be excised from the lease, because at that stage there was a track for initiates to go to another area where certain secret ceremonies would take place.

During the last six months various actions have been brought in the Federal Court and Supreme Court respectively by the Yawuru corporation. In fact, the Kimberley Land Council has become involved, and it was at the request of the Kimberley Land Council that the federal Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) intervened and used his power under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act.

Before I get to that matter, it is worthwhile to note that four attempts were made in the courts to seek injunctions against the development of this property and they all failed. In the latest decision in the Supreme Court of Western Australia, Mr Justice Owen stated:

For these reasons I do not believe that the plaintiffs' native title (assuming it to exist) is seriously at risk of irreparable injury. If an injunction is not granted and the defendants proceed to develop the area they do so with full knowledge of the plaintiffs' claim and, I would assume, an understanding of the consequences should the plaintiffs succeed in obtaining final relief.

What then is the real risk to the plaintiffs? As I have said, and with one possible exception, I am not convinced that the spiritual and cultural integrity of Yawuru is seriously at risk by an interference with what is a relatively small and discrete portion of the total area claimed.

SPEECH.PARA: What he was saying there was that there was, as he saw it, no serious risk of irreparable injury or harm as such. He went on to discuss the initiates track that went alongside the leased area. He stated:

One of the other difficulties alluded to by the plaintiffs was the need for secrecy in these ceremonies. It was submitted that the element of secrecy would be compromised by the initiates having to pass in close proximity to a crocodile park. There are three things to be said about this. The Lease abuts a major road and a minor road and is in an area that already has various forms of development. Secondly, I was told from the bar table without objection that the plans for the crocodile park require the construction of levy banks on the side facing the mangroves. These banks are to be vegetated. This will preserve some measure of privacy for persons passing along the fringes of the mangroves. Thirdly, p12 of the Mardiros Report—
which is the Kimberley Land Council report that I mentioned—
suggests that the rite of passage is carried out "under the cover of darkness". For all these reasons I do not think that the issue of secrecy is sufficient to tip the balance.

What Mr Justice Owen said was that, on the balance of interests, he found in favour of not granting the injunction against the development. Mr Justice Owen, a most erudite judge of the Supreme Court of Western Australia, readily acknowledged:

PARA.TAB: I believe that there would be overwhelming support from the population generally for the proposition that Aboriginal culture should not be allowed to disappear. It is generally recognised that the ancient culture incorporates a spiritual closeness to the land.

SPEECH.PARA: What I am saying to the Senate is that this was a very carefully considered judgment by a judge of the Supreme Court of Western Australia who was well seized of the issues which were before him. He approached it with a sensitivity and aforethought which I believe make his reasons compelling reading. Nonetheless, despite that injunction having been rejected by Mr Justice Owen, the federal minister chose to intervene. He intervened so that we now have a development placed at great risk.

PARA.TAB: It is worth while remembering the purposes that are mentioned for which the land is required. They are enumerated by Mr Douglas as: first, for a commercial crocodile farm and research facility; second, for a tourism and education display; third, for an area where problem or rogue crocodiles from the wild can be relocated for breeding and display, which is in accordance with the CALM policy—the land management department; and, fourth, for a training facility for Aborigines who wish to develop their own crocodile farms, for example, the Pandanus community. It is a fact that a large percentage of the Kimberley Aborigines want the new crocodile farm for this purpose and for a place to relocate animals that threaten their communities.

Mr Douglas has advised me personally that this venture entails the full-time employment of eight people and the employment of some 20-odd part-timers. It would be his intention to provide a training facility for local Aborigines. I put it to the Senate that he has approached this matter with a great deal of caution and aforethought. He could provide to the local community an income of some $500,000 per annum by way of export and he has told me personally that, in an effort to avoid such confrontation, he has tried to seek alternative venues.

The availability of land in Broome is not great. In fact, for what he requires there is really only this particular lot. This block is important because it has brackish water which he can use; it has power; it is well positioned for tourism; and there are also banks sloping down to mangroves and to a marsh area, which are ideal for his farming. The minister has really overstepped the mark in his intervention and declaration which have held up this development for the next 30 days.

Mr Douglas indicated to me that he was not consulted, that such a halt on his development could well place this development in financial jeopardy, and that he might have to find himself relocating the crocodile farm to the Northern Territory. That would be a great shame for the people of Broome—for both the Aboriginal community and the wider community. It would be a great shame for the reasons that I have pointed out in relation to the financial aspects and the other more community-minded aspects of this development.

I do not believe the minister has acted in the best interests of the local Aboriginal community. I believe this is a blatant interference with the local land management by a local council and the state government concerned. It is an intervention which has no basis in merit. I put to the Senate that the recent Native Title Act in itself allowed for past acts, such as the grant of this lease, to stand. It allowed those acts to stand, but also allowed for the question of compensation to be sorted out. I put to the Senate that the federal minister has acted in contravention of the spirit of the very act which he fought so hard to introduce in December last year.

This motion was framed with careful thought and I believe has great merit. In this instance the federal minister has behaved in an entirely inappropriate fashion and has abused his power under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act. I commend the motion to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before arguing the case on behalf of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner), I take this opportunity to compliment Senator Ellison on his presentation. We have seen in this place, and indeed in other parliaments, that issues relating to Aboriginal land rights sometimes bring forth a style of confrontation and aggression in such a way that the arguments are lost because of the presentational style. As I found, when I served with Senator Ellison on the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee that considered the Native Title Bill, his arguments are always clearly presented in a totally unemotional style. We need to see more of that style of presentation, not just in this place but also throughout parliaments in this country and in the community.

PARA.TAB: We are debating Senator Campbell's motion in relation to the Broome crocodile farm. I have some material to present on behalf of Minister Tickner, to whose activities this motion refers. Minister Tickner advises that he first received an application from the Kimberley Land Council, acting on behalf of the Aerie community, seeking protection under sections 9 and 10 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984, with respect to a proposed crocodile farm in Broome in June 1993. Any argument or proposition that the minister could have been acting without due powers is clearly not the case.

On 31 January 1994 this application was followed with an application for urgent protection of the area under section 9, together with an application under section 10. The applicant was concerned that the development of the farm would impact upon an area of land significant for the preservation of Aboriginal tradition and culture. The area of land concerned is vacant crown land over which the Western Australian government has purported to issue a lease and over which the local Aboriginal custodians have asserted a claim to native title.

As a result of a breakdown in discussions with the Western Australian government and the Kimberley Land Council, acting on behalf of the Aboriginal custodians, and because construction activity commenced earlier in the week, on Friday, 4 December, Minister Tickner made a declaration, under section 9 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984, to provide emergency protection to the area. In addition to issuing that declaration, he issued an invitation to the parties to seek a mediated resolution of the issue.

As the honourable senator will be aware, in the native title legislation we focused on the importance of the mediation—reconciliation, if you like—of negotiated regional agreements. Although I have not been directly involved, I hope honourable senators who will be speaking in this debate can ensure that their parties take up Minister Tickner's invitation for a round table mediation process.

The minister can justify issuing the declaration on the basis of section 9 because it allows for declarations to be made which protect sites in the short term until there can be a mediation process to resolve the issues of obvious concern to all parties. In this case, the minister was satisfied that the site is significant to Aboriginal people and that it was under serious and immediate danger of injury or desecration. Such a declaration does not in any way interfere or prejudge any application that Aboriginal people may have made claiming native title to this area.

The Native Title Act 1993 does not cover the protection of sacred or significant sites. This is a matter left to the existing laws, such as the Heritage Protection Act. This declaration does not cut across the jurisdiction of the Western Australian courts to determine issues of native title. The Heritage Protection Act is an act of last resort to be used when state and territory laws are not followed or are inadequate. The minister was satisfied that this was the case in this area. This declaration allows for Aboriginal interests in the development to be properly considered before any major interference with the site takes place.

I come to the very specific areas of Senator Campbell's motion. In response to paragraph (a), the minister advises that, although Mr Douglas has talked about his proposal for an extension to the present Broome crocodile park for some years, he did not pursue environmental approval under the processes established by the Western Australian Environmental Protection Authority until 1992. He sought clearance under the processes of the Western Australian Aboriginal Heritage Act in 1991. However, because he ignored the advice of the Western Australian Aboriginal sites department—acting on a determination of the Aboriginal Cultural Materials Committee established under that act—as to the proper procedures for obtaining that clearance, the process was delayed for a considerable time.

In December 1992 the Aboriginal Cultural Materials Committee determined that no development should proceed on the area without the consent of the Yawuru, the Aboriginal custodians for this area. The minister further advises that the local Aboriginal group is constituted by the Yawuru Aboriginal Corporation, acting on behalf of the Aboriginal custodians, and this group has consistently opposed development of this kind in this area. There is no evidence to suggest that there is any other group which represents custodians for this area. After considerable anthropological investigation of land ownership in the area, there is no suggestion that the Yawuru Aboriginal Corporation does not properly represent the custodians. There is certainly no evidence of any other group supporting this development as suggested in this section of the motion.

In regard to paragraph (b), the declaration issued by the minister is an emergency declaration which expires in 30 days, giving time for the parties to attempt to resolve the matter by a process of mediation. From the way Senator Ellison addressed this debate, perhaps he could use his good offices, together with other Western Australian senators, to see if this mediation process cannot resolve the current impasse. The federal act is an act of last resort, and it is important.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think we should go to Broome at the weekend and try to sort it out?

—I am suggesting that there are telephones and there are faxes. I believe that it is important that every encouragement is given to the mediation process. This is what we should have learnt from the native title debate. We do not need to always assume that these issues can only be resolved in courts or tribunals. If people could only learn to sit down and talk to each other face to face, I am sure we would get a lot further.

PARA.TAB: Finally, in relation to paragraph (c) of Senator Campbell's motion, the minister advises that he has taken this action under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act. This act has been in place for almost a decade. Action was taken only upon a proper consideration of the issues involved in protecting an Aboriginal area of significance. It is not an action taken under the provisions of the Native Title Act; nor has it any relevance to that act. However, if the Western Australian government, which issued a special purpose lease to Mr Douglas, had observed the procedures of the Native Title Act, this dispute may well have been avoided.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I am a senator from Victoria, I support my Western Australian colleagues on this motion. To forestall any question of relevance, I wish to indicate how the situation mentioned in paragraph (b) of the motion could be applied to Victoria.

PARA.TAB: We can learn a great deal from this situation when we look at it from the national point of view. The usefulness of the Murray Island title has a limited application. TALK.START.PARA: —The only land not claimable is freehold. On my calculations, this would leave something like 38 per cent of land able to be acted on by native title.

PARA.TAB: Because there have been no test cases and the validity of this act has yet to be proved, this simply serves to underline the fact that there are many grey areas in this whole question. I feel that many of the questions that Senator Ellison has raised in respect to the area at Broome could equally be applied to many areas of Victoria. All the land is shown in the Auslig map as freehold. Some small parcels of land which will be subject to native title simply do not show up on a map of this scale.

In rural and regional Victoria many areas which have been targeted as suitable for future development under the Kelty report can be, and no doubt will be, subject to native title claims. This will lead to economic uncertainty. Senator Reynolds pointed out that the perspective being given by the minister was a short-term one. When many businesses are choosing where they are going to locate they have to choose a short-term perspective because, if they cannot do anything in the medium to short term, they will simply move away and locate elsewhere—either elsewhere in Australia or offshore.

Claimants to native title will have the right to exclude other persons from their land. I feel very strongly that this will work in a very negative manner when businesses are looking to locate their industries. Many of the small businesses in Victoria are on small parcels of land. Industries such as tourism and food technology are going to be located in regional areas such as the Latrobe Valley and the Goulburn Valley which the Kelty report nominated as suitable for development.

The validity of the Native Title Act has yet to be determined by the High Court and until then uncertainty, delay and expense similar to that undergone by Mr Douglas will be undergone by many small businesses. It would be regrettable to see this situation repeated in thousands of small businesses across Australia. Yet, with the implications of this particular case as outlined by my colleague Senator Ellison, I fear that it will be so.

TALK.START.PARA: —In essence, what the Senate is debating this afternoon in the context of Senator Campbell's motion is the matter of state rights rather than the content of the motion. I do not hold the view that states have got rights, but I strongly hold the view that people have got rights. The intervention by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, on this matter is an exercise in the protection of people's rights. A group of people in Broome, Western Australia, have sought the assistance of the minister as a last resort to protect what they see as their rights. The minister has, quite properly, having regard to his right and obligation as a minister of the crown, exercised the powers conferred on him through legislation to put a stay of execution on that particular development in north-west Western Australia—a quite proper course of action.

PARA.TAB: My colleague from Queensland Senator Reynolds earlier in the debate addressed some of the technical and legal points attached to the minister's decision in using the powers conferred on him under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act to stop, for the moment, if not for a longer period of time, the proposed development of a crocodile farm in Broome, Western Australia.

I do not, unfortunately, have the full text of Senator Campbell's motion in front of me. Rather than addressing the matter of whether this particular commercial development should or should not be allowed to go ahead, I would rather address the more important question—not that I am dismissive of the development application—of people's rights in a democracy such as Australia.
Reference has been made so far in the debate to the Native Title Bill which was exhaustively debated in this chamber at the end of last year, which was the International Year of Indigenous People.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have only scratched the surface.
—If Senator Panizza thinks we only scratched the surface, it is his fault. The filibustering that went on should have been put to one side.
—There was no filibustering.

—Come on, Senator Panizza, be honest. He knows, I know and, more importantly, the community of Australia knows, there was a very well managed filibustering debate on that most important piece of legislation that went through the Senate. Those who were in this chamber witnessed the rotation of opposition senators as they came in to make their contributions to the debate. If we only scratched the surface in doing that, that was not the fault of those on this side of the chamber. Although it was filibustering, I agree there was quite a deal of very good debate that went on during the extended committee stage of that bill.

PARA.TAB: That bill is important, not only for Aboriginal people but also for people in all parts of Australia, even though some people in some of the more remote states like Western Australia, Queensland and the Northern Territory have been dismissive of it. It is an important bill, and further action will flow from it this year. I realise, Mr Acting Deputy President, I am perhaps straying from the essence and direct words contained in Senator Campbell's motion that is before the chamber, but I have given the explanation that I want to address the wider question of the rights of people.

Here we have a group of people—Aboriginal people, as it turns out—who are living in a distant part of Senator Panizza's and my home state. They have a view that the area in which this proposed development is going to take place is an area of importance to them—historic and, more importantly, cultural importance. They have sought, through the measures available to them within the legislation governing such things in Western Australia, to protect that area and they have not been successful.

Despite the fact that we are a federation of states, which can be cumbersome from time to time, we are a nation. As citizens of the nation of Australia, they have every right to approach the Commonwealth Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs to ask him to exercise the powers conferred on him under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act to stop that proposal. It is not a permanent stop imposed by Mr Tickner. I understand it will last for 30 days. It is an interim measure which will be reviewed within the 30-day period. As with other applications and interim decisions made by previous ministers in this portfolio, it can be overturned down the line.

What springs to my mind very quickly on this matter is the matter of the redevelopment of the Swan Brewery site, on the banks of the Swan River in Perth. Similar actions by a previous minister holding this portfolio put a stay on the development for a period of time. We all know that the redevelopment of the old Swan Brewery building has gone ahead and that resolution was reached as to whether or not it was a site of great importance to Aboriginal people. Not everybody in our community accepted that.

TALK.START.PARA: —But there was a Labor mate involved, wasn't there?
—A Labor mate?
—Yes.
—What was his name?
—John Roberts.
—Was he the person who assisted Graeme Campbell?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! Senator McKiernan, could you address your remarks through the chair? I know it is rather difficult when senators on my left are interjecting, but I would ask you to return to the subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do appreciate your comments, Mr Acting Deputy President. I will bring myself to order and address my remarks through you to my colleagues opposite. The reference made in the interjection was that the government in Western Australia, and perhaps even the government at the Commonwealth level, took action at the time to protect a Labor mate. I am not certain where the Labor mate fits in. I recall one demonstration that took place on that site which was extensively reported live on radio stations—I was in my electorate office at the time—by television stations that night and in the print media the next day. It was a counter demonstration in support of the development organised by my colleague the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Graeme Campbell. He assisted in bringing some Aboriginal people down to Perth to press the then Labor government in Western Australia to continue with the redevelopment of the site. Where the `Labor mate' fits in, I am not entirely certain. Whether or not Mr Roberts is a Labor mate, I really cannot tell. If he is, fine, and if he is not, that is empty rhetoric on behalf of those opposite in this debate.

PARA.TAB: The redevelopment did proceed. The outside of the building has now been completed; the refurbishment inside the building was due to start last Monday. I believe that redevelopment is continuing to go ahead with the support of the present Western Australian state government, which is not, of course, a Labor government. If the inference in the earlier interjections is that—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! We seem to be getting away from the subject somewhat, due largely to the interjections on my left.

—With all due respect, I am trying to use an instance in my home state where the minister for Aboriginal affairs had exercised on an interim basis his powers under the Aboriginal heritage protection act. That was later overturned in a very important development for the people of Perth and Western Australia. I use that as an example for what is currently happening in Broome in Western Australia to show that, whilst an exercise of ministerial power has been made, it does not necessarily mean that is the end of the story. Other measures are available to all parties involved in the current dispute in Broome. I was merely using that as an example rather than straying from the debate itself. As I said in my opening remarks, the important issue is people's rights, and Minister Tickner would say he is exercising his powers to protect those rights.

PARA.TAB: I will now finish my saga about the Swan Brewery redevelopment. I have made the point that the interior refurbishment of that building is going ahead with the support of the current Western Australian government, which is not a Labor government. Unfortunately for those on our side of the chamber, the Western Australian government is now under the stewardship of Premier Court. It is supportive of what is happening at the Swan building. I understand that Mr Roberts is still involved in its redevelopment. Is one to imply from that that Mr Roberts is now a Liberal mate? I will not do that because I do not engage in the empty rhetoric that sometimes emanates from the opposition benches.

It is useful that matters such as this are addressed in this chamber. The issue itself is obviously of very great importance to the Aboriginal people in Broome and to the developer there. It is also of importance to the Western Australian state government. Of course, from our position as legislators at the Commonwealth level, it is important to us. It is good that the debate as been so measured and controlled so far. Senator Reynolds complimented Senator Ellison on his measured and thoughtful remarks and on the fact that he did not seek to generate any heat in this debate. I have tried to contain my remarks and reflect the tone of debate adopted by Senator Ellison.

The only point I make in conclusion is that the exercise of ministerial power in this instance is not the end of the story. There are many other measures contained in the legislation which the developer, the Aboriginal people, the state government and the federal government can exercise in order to protect all interests in this matter. It has also given those concerned time in which to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened carefully to what both Senator Reynolds and Senator McKiernan had to say on this matter. They gave some very good arguments in support of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) and his actions. Unfortunately, I believe Minister Tickner was sold a pup and Senator Reynolds and Senator McKiernan have gone along with it. If the land concerned was the people's traditional land, I would have listened to their argument. But the facts are that the claim on the crocodile farm near Broome in Western Australia is being brought by the Kimberley Land Council on behalf of the Yawuru group. However, according to Aboriginal traditions the crocodile farm lies within the territory attributed to the Djugun people and not the group that is making the application.

PARA.TAB: The Djugun group is now deceased, but one senior Aboriginal lawman remains and he married a Djugun woman. In fact, this Djugun group died out over the years, but one woman, for the want of a better description, took off with a fellow from another tribe and moved away. But eventually they came back to take their punishment and that having happened, this fellow who married the Djugun woman was taught the traditions, songs, sites knowledge and ceremonies by the Djugun people. He has primary custodial responsibility for the Djugun territory, which includes the proposed crocodile farm. So the Yawuru group is certainly out of order in trying to lay a claim or in asking Minister Tickner to put things on hold for 28 days.

This senior lawman was consulted by the relevant Western Australian government department five years ago and made it clear that there were no sacred sites in the area in question. Both Senator Reynolds and Senator McKiernan mentioned sacred sites, but the only one of the Djugun people who can speak for that piece of ground said that there were no sacred sites five years ago. And a Labor government, not a Liberal government, was in power at that time.

In 1984, the Kimberley Land Council—KLC—commissioned and received a report by Maria Mann and Ian Kirkby which stated that the area in question was not Yawuru territory whatsoever. The report is a public document and a copy of it is held with the Crown Law Department of Western Australia. It is as simple as that.

The area in question lies on what is locally known as the Broome marsh. Those who have not been to Broome will know that the area is surrounded by a lot of marsh country. In the 1950s and 1960s there existed a curfew under which Aboriginal people were not permitted within the Broome town site after 6.00 p.m. The Aboriginal people therefore used the marsh as a fringe camp. The proposed crocodile farm lies adjacent to the old fringe camp. A survey of the locality revealed no archaeological material. This is an area of only contemporary interest. Incidentally, that Broome marsh holds other things, such as the relic of a Catalina which was involved in the evacuation of people from Singapore. The aircraft crash-landed in the area and was never able to get out of the mud.

A ceremonial site has been documented at One Mile Creek, or, to use the local name, Nillirr Ibanjin. Another site of some significance lies at Fisherman's Bend at Broome. The Yawuru—in other words, the KLC in this case—contends that a dreaming track extends between these two localities. The alleged track crosses a tidal creek on the crocodile farm. The Western Australian government has sought to excise the alleged track, but this action would not suit the purpose of those supporting the Yawuru claim.

In response, the Yawuru allege that the track moves with the tide. We are getting into a bit of fantasy land when it is said that the track moves with the tide, but that is what they say. The crocodile farm was originally an environmental issue with regard to the Broome marsh. Aboriginals put forward the concern that such an accumulation of crocodiles may lead to a situation where an escaping reptile may pose a threat to Aboriginal children. I say that it would pose a threat to more than Aboriginal children. However, in response the proponent of the crocodile farm then offered to construct substantial fencing to negate any such possible threat.

Two years ago, there was a push by the Yawuru people for recognition. However, they needed a platform to do that. They did not have one, so they made this crocodile farm their platform to gain respectability. The crocodile farm became that platform despite Yawuru's lack of Aboriginal proof, such as songs, ceremonies and sites knowledge. As I told honourable senators at the outset of my remarks, that land belonged to the Djugun people and the one lawman left there said that there is no-one else except him who can speak for it and that there is no sacred sites, and that lawman has full custodianship.

The contemporary political clout of the Yawuru—in other words, the KLC—has overwhelmed the traditional custodial responsibilities of the Djugun territory. Of course, with the KLC backed by this government at every turn, it has been able to override the wishes of the people to whom, traditionally, the ground belongs. Why are the Yawuru people able to bring such pressure? For the benefit of you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and other Tasmanians, and the rest of the Senate, I will explain.

To answer this question we must not forget that the head of the Kimberley Land Council is Peter Yu, a man of Yawuru descent, coincidentally. Another man claiming Yawuru descent is Pat Dodson, formerly director of the Central Land Council and more recently chairman of Mr Keating's reconciliation committee. So we can see where it all ties together. Where is the reconciliation in this case? One group has been pushed out and taken over by the KLC. But the KLC does not represent everyone in the Kimberley; it represents only half the people—about 2,000 out of 4,000. So we can see how these things are going down the track.

In this case Mr Tickner simply overrode the state laws. Why? In my view, it was to repay some of the favours that the KLC delivered to Mr Tickner and this government so that they could say there was consensus on the Mabo legislation. Remember that the KLC represents only half the people. Yesterday I had at least three phone calls from the Utemurrah crowd emphasising that the KLC speaks for only half the people. The best message I can send to Mr Tickner is that he should do his homework before he jumps in with these 28-day reprieves. He should make sure that he knows what he is talking about and who owns the ground in question. Then he can come to a decision. I am afraid all he has done is interfere in state land management, and the best advice I can give him is to get his nose out of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to rebut a couple of the points made earlier in the debate by Senator Reynolds and by my West Australian colleague Senator McKiernan. Senator Reynolds, I think in a very genuine spirit of trying to solve the problem and reconcile the differences between the people who have lobbied the federal Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) to intervene in this, and the developer and the other Aboriginals in Broome, said that we should use our good offices to try to create mediation.

PARA.TAB: I am afraid that Senator Reynolds does not understand the process that has been gone through, certainly for the last four years. Malcolm Douglas, the developer, has very actively pursued a constructive approach to dealing with the local Aboriginal communities. Indeed, it is the sort of cooperation on the ground, the sort of community involvement and the sort of community reconciliation and discussion that all of us would like to see take place through the reconciliation process that is being pursued nationally at the moment.

The other point Senator Reynolds made was that Mr Douglas had not pursued the environmental approvals process until 1992. To begin with I remind Senator Reynolds that we are now two years down the track from 1992 anyway, and that is an enormously long time. This government is saying that the 14-month procedure under the national land rights legislation we recently put through is a relatively quick approval process—and that is a 14-month approval process when there was no confusion over who the claimants were and when everything went fairly smoothly. Here we are, two years down the track, and Senator Reynolds is saying that Mr Douglas has been a bit lax because he only started the approvals process in 1992. I wonder how long she expects an environmental approval process should take.

The reality is that back in 1990—which is much longer ago than Senator Reynolds would have the Senate believe—Mr Douglas instigated his discussions with the Environmental Protection Authority in Western Australia. In fact, the preliminary discussions for the whole project took place in 1987, so we are talking about an extremely long lead time. Mr Douglas started preparing his environmental assessments and all the other parts of the process as early as 1991.

Senator Ellison has already gone through the detailed process that Mr Malcolm Douglas went through to get to this stage. I will not retread that ground, except to rebut what Senator Reynolds said about the environmental process and the mediation. The mediation that has taken place on the ground—the discussions and the consultations—has been taking place since 1987 to the extent, as Senator Panizza said, that the elder lawman, the traditional custodians of the Broome area, have not only said they have no objections to the development, but also have cooperated through all the Aboriginal heritage processes. They are very keen to see this project go ahead to get rid of the crocodile risk to young children and, particularly, to see genuine job opportunities for young Aboriginals.

We are witnessing a process in Broome where the minister has moved in and used his ministerial discretion to stop the project after Mr Douglas has spent years and years going through all the approvals processes. The scary parallel is that the national land rights legislation that we passed here in December has exactly the same problem built into it.

Under the national land rights scheme that was put through this chamber late in December, the approvals process starts off basically with the state minister forming an intention to allow a development to go ahead. That can take a couple of months or a few weeks—the quickest is about 70 days for a mine, and probably longer for things like tourism developments. The whole process kicks off with a state minister forming an intention to approve a development, be it mining, tourism or anything else. We then go into what is called the notification period—a period of two months during which all the people in the area are given notification that it is intended to proceed with a development. That allows all who are interested in the area to register as negotiating parties before the tribunal.

There is then a two-month period of submissions and negotiations and a further four to six months when there are applications to the tribunal, and the tribunal makes a determination. The determination is either approved or not approved—there is an appeal process to the minister—and the proposal either goes ahead or it does not go ahead. That whole process takes a minimum of about 10 months and a maximum of about 14 months if all goes smoothly. That is the national land rights process that was established with the support of this Senate only a few weeks ago. At the very end of that process there is power in the act for the minister to override it. So there can actually be the whole process of consultations with Aboriginal groups, the determination as to who the native title claimants are and all the environmental and heritage approvals, but at the end of it the Commonwealth minister again has that power to overrule the decision made by the tribunal.

Even if, at the end of all those deliberations and considerations, the minister, in some sort of good faith, says `I don't intend to exercise that power', that is irrelevant because, if there is an aggrieved party, it can lobby the minister in exactly the way that occurred with Mr Tickner when this notice was lodged on Friday, and create political pressure. Even if the minister said on the first day after the approval had been granted, `I am not going to exercise my right to overrule the decision of the tribunal', he can change his mind up to two months after the tribunal has made its decision. The minister can do exactly as Mr Tickner did on Friday and say, `No, it is not going ahead'.

Basically, his word is the end of it; the development is finished and the people have wasted the entire process. In all good faith, we can have developers, state governments, local governments and Aboriginal communities go through this tedious process of approvals, on top of the existing approvals processes of the state governments. And we should not kid ourselves about this land rights scheme; it is said that a lot of these approvals processes can be done concurrently, but many of them cannot. The very sad thing is that, after all that, we can get to the stage where the federal minister says no, and it is all over.

The Aboriginal people, particularly, can benefit in terms of employment and opportunities in the tourism, eco-tourism, mining and pastoral industries, and the construction of pipelines and other infrastructure that can develop in the north of the state—although, as Senator Troth has said, this can also happen in Victoria and, indeed, all other parts of Australia. The scary thing for Aboriginals is that these sorts of developments in remote areas are an essential ingredient in trying to reconcile Australians and create the opportunities for Aboriginals that all of us would like to see so that they can develop to their full potential.

What is so very sad about this is that when developers and entrepreneurs see this sort of action by the federal minister, which will occur under the national land rights scheme, they will not bother. These are people such as Malcolm Douglas, who are great Australians, who have these dreams to build these sorts of projects—he started in 1987 with this idea and has pursued it all the way. Not only will mining companies such as CRA, Western Mining and BHP not bother to explore for minerals in Australia, but also small entrepreneurs and tourist operators—people who come up with ideas and want to go through the development process—will not even wonder. They will stick to what they are doing—they will stick to their knitting—and will not develop these great ideas that have made Australia the great country it is. Entrepreneurs like Keith Williams, who developed Sea World and Hamilton Island—people who have ideas, vision, enthusiasm and who make these projects come together. They develop Australia and, therefore, jobs and, particularly in the remote areas, help the Aboriginal people who this minister seeks to pretend he is helping.

There is another example in Australia of a serious reflection on the Minister, Mr Tickner. We have seen in the case which I have just outlined, which is the subject of my motion today, that Mr Tickner will, under the political pressure of the Aboriginal industry—which in many parts of Australia does not represent the grassroots traditional Aboriginals—act to stop a development that has the support of many of the traditional Aboriginals in the Broome area.

Mr Tickner went to Western Australia and appeared on the Sattler File, Howard Sattler's talkback, and said, `Don't worry. Western Australia has got nothing to worry about. We are not going to stop development'. But the first chance he got he went to Western Australia, in his laconic sort of way, with his big friendly smile that he wears, and stopped this development. He wants Western Australians to believe that with the extra power he now has of management over land in Western Australia with his national land rights scheme, he will not stop development. How many days was it after the National Land Rights Act was proclaimed that Robert Tickner went across to Western Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —About 55 minutes!
—That is right. It was not very long at all. He is over there stopping development that has the agreement of all the local communities and the support of many local Aboriginals.

PARA.TAB: It reminds me of the song that I hear when I am at home playing with my little son Edward which says, `Never smile at a crocodile. Tilt your hat and stop to talk awhile. Don't be taken in by his cheery grin—' remember that Mr Tickner has this lovely, cheery grin. He is a happy man because he is just imagining `how good you'll feel beneath his skin'. So when Mr Tickner says, `We are not going to stop development. Trust me, I'm a good bloke. I'm from Canberra. I'm from the government. I'm here to help you', do not be taken in by his cheery grin because he is there to overrule—not states' rights, as Senator McKiernan is talking about—people's rights. When one is trying to make decisions balancing the interests of development against Aboriginal rights, and development against the environment, the best people to make the decisions are those who are on the ground.

People in Broome regard the southerners such as Senator Panizza and me as being too far away, out of contact and out of touch with the local community; that is very true. We are not as good at making decisions for Broome as the people in Broome are. The local councils and the local Aboriginals made a decision which was supported by the state government, but this minister, who lives 3000 miles away—I think it is a four and a half hour direct flight in a Falcon jet, going at thunderbolt speed to get there—knows better because he has been lobbied by the Kimberley Land Council, and he rolled over.

It was very different when it came to being lobbied by Aboriginal people in Perth over the brewery site. The person who was developing the site had donated $800,000-odd in one year to the Australian Labor Party, so Mr Tickner did not stop him.

I said I would refer to one more case. It is a very sad case where the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs did not stick up for the rights of the traditional Aboriginal owners of the land. It is the Amadeus claim near Ayres Rock—near Lake Amadeus. I think it was in 1988—I do not have the documents in front of me—that the Federal Court found in favour of the traditional lawmen and custodians of that Amadeus claim area and made a finding against the Central Lands Council, which was a competing claimant.

Since then the minister has failed to grant that land to the successful claimants. He has ignored the Federal Court ruling on who are the traditional owners of the land. The common law sits there and he has ignored it because it does not suit him politically—he would rather have the Central Land Council in control of that land. After this ruling was made, and after Mr Tickner has ignored the Federal Court and the local traditional Aboriginals, we now have the Central Land Council building dwellings on this land that the Federal Court found to be owned by the traditional lawmen of that district. This shows the bona fides of this minister who cries crocodile tears for traditional Aboriginal owners, passes rapacious national rights legislation which will override people's rights in remote areas, but will not even grant the land to the traditional owners of the Amadeus area.

Western Australians are very worried about having decisions over land shifted 3000 miles away to Canberra. We in Western Australia have a very deep interest in ensuring that Aboriginal Australians have great opportunities and that they have their health, housing and educational problems addressed with a very good balance between development and assistance; and we want to ensure that that takes place with reconciliation at a local community level. But these interventions from afar are one sure way of ensuring that reconciliation does not take place. There will be suspicion of the federal government and suspicion of the Kimberley Land Council and its motivations. We will have division between Aboriginals and white Australians. That will tear Australia apart not put it together.

I urge the Senate, particularly those on the cross-benches, to support this motion. Honourable senators who are interested in reconciliation and in providing employment opportunities for young Aboriginals, and ensuring that Australia progresses into the next century as a unified nation and not one divided on the ground of race, should be appalled by this action of the minister who says one thing one day and does another the next.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Campbell's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
