TALK.START.PARA: —We have had quite a vigorous debate in this chamber and in the other place over the very generous treatment afforded to Mr Kelly, the Comptroller-General of Customs. The issue I wish to raise relates to a similar problem but it has been treated in a very dissimilar manner. I refer to the two housekeepers at the Lodge who, as I said in this chamber the other day, received a phone call one Sunday night and were told not to report for duty the following morning.

PARA.TAB: Basically they have been treated in a shabby way. Accusations have been made publicly against their character. The other day I tabled in this chamber the certificates of service that were given to these two housekeepers. It is important to note that the certificates of service said that the two housekeepers—and there is a similar sentence in each certificate of service—had provided competent housekeeping services during the term of their employment.

The certificates of service went on to explain that because of the need for changes in staffing arrangements at the residence, the services of these housekeepers were no longer required. In other words, the certificates of service show that they provided competent service and that because of changes in the staffing arrangements they were no longer required.

That, to the individuals involved, would be disappointing, but I recognise that Mr and Mrs Keating have the right to choose whom they want to have working with them at the Lodge. My only complaint is that people who are employees have to be treated with fairness and decency. I believe this whole affair involving the two housekeepers is an example of two people being treated in a harsh and unjust manner.

I have provided the certificates of service to the Senate. This evening I want to provide other references for these two housekeepers and for the work that they did at the Lodge. One of the housekeepers has a note provided by Mr and Mrs Keating as recently as August last year—just some months before the dismissal took place. It is on a card to one of the

SPEECH.PARA: them. The name of the housekeeper is mentioned. The note says, `With warmest best wishes on your birthday, and with great appreciation for your care and attention to us all'. It is signed: Paul and Annita Keating.

PARA.TAB: To the other housekeeper there was, on a Christmas card at the end of 1992, a note written by Mr and Mrs Keating. It says to the housekeeper, who is named:

SPEECH.PARA: With appreciation for your support through 1992, particularly with the children. It has made the Lodge a much more livable family environment. Best wishes for Christmas and for 1993. Paul and Annitta Keating.

PARA.TAB: These were nice personal notes from the Prime Minister and his wife to two people who had served them loyally. In each of those two personal notes they recognised the competence and attention to duty of these two housekeepers. How different is the sentiment in those two comments from the statements made by an official from the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet, and Senator Gareth Evans, at the estimates hearings at the end of October. I think it is a fair reading of the evidence given that the Senate committee was told in a variety of ways that the housekeepers had not performed their duty, they had not followed instructions in relation to the use of credit cards, and there were difficulties at the Lodge.

Bringing us up to date, we have documentary evidence from the department about the competence of these people. We have personal references and personal notes from the Prime Minister and his wife expressing their gratitude for the kindness of these two people; and we contrast this with the evidence that was given at the Senate committee.

Madam Acting Deputy President, I am glad that you are in the chair because I know of your great concern for women and your sense of justice and fairness. It is possible that you may be able to do something to help support these two women who are still without employment, as one would expect after having those very harsh things said about them before a Senate committee.

I have brought this to the attention of the Senate. I still think the facts of this case are very confusing and that the department has simply not produced the documentary evidence to support its assertions. It is my hope that this matter will be resolved quickly and decently. I hope the Prime Minister and his wife will intervene in this matter and make sure that justice is done to these people who, I believe, have served the Prime Minister and his wife in a very loyal fashion.

If Mr Keating does not decide to take that course—I think it will be a pity and it is sad that two people who have served the Prime Minister loyally should be treated in this fashion—then it is important that an independent investigation be established. Madam Acting Deputy President, you will be aware that the Ombudsman is considering this matter. I hope that the Ombudsman will move to quickly establish an independent investigation into this matter if it cannot be resolved in any other way.

I have brought to the attention of the Senate this evening further evidence which I think establishes the competence and the decency of these two women. In the absence of any other contrary evidence I think it is fair to assume that justice has not been done in this case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A couple of nights ago I raised a matter of interest that I thought was important for the Senate to consider. That is the matter of forests near Deloraine in Tasmania. I was followed in my contribution by Senator Gibson who said:

SPEECH.PARA: To actually suggest we should take interest in compartment X or compartment Y here or there in a particular part of Australia—that the Commonwealth government has a right to consider and should know all the details of that—I find absolutely unbelievable.

It is my opinion—and I believe many other honourable senators would share my opinion—that this chamber should be interested in such matters. We have heard from Senator Kemp, who thinks we should be interested in the kitchen at Yarralumla. I do not disagree with that. Senator Campbell recently made the case for the Senate being interested in the crocodile farm at Broome. These matters add to the sorts of things that are considered important by various honourable senators. I do not disagree with them one iota. In fact, I would like to return to the matter of the forests near Deloraine and other forests in Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: Nothing is more vital to our survival than the maintenance of this planet's biodiversity. When a forest is destroyed, so also are its dependent flora and fauna, and so in turn our collective vitality is diminished.

Recently, in Hobart, the Australian network for plant conservation considered the plight of some 3,500 Australian plant types that are threatened with extinction. Some are reduced to a mere handful of plants surviving in a few square metres. Others are differently threatened. The conference attended by many experts from around the world emphasised that any threat to biodiversity must be viewed very seriously indeed. That threat is merely part of the broader threat to the existence of all living things.

In this realisation the Reedy Marsh forest conservation group calls for the conservation of all natural public forests of the Reedy Marsh area and asserts its right to see public land remain intact, with all its natural values, both for future Australians and all other life forms that live in the forest. But the group goes further. It rightly calls upon the state government of Tasmania to implement a moratorium to save all remaining natural dry forests on the island. Under terms of the national forest strategy, the federal government must support the Reedy Marsh forest conservation group in its call for such a moratorium.

Until the emergence of the woodchip industry in Tasmania in 1971, the dry forests were used for low intensity, selective logging and grazing. The amount of sawlog declined because the selective logging of these forests for sawlogs was unsustainable, even at that time. Current clear-felling practices emerged later. Those practices are grossly destructive and widespread throughout the state. Public consultation concerning these practices has been minimal and criticism is suppressed and continues to be suppressed. There is little political will to solve the problem in Tasmania and proper land use planning mechanisms do not exist.

Although the Tasmanian state government was granted federal funds in 1990 to resolve the conflict over Tasmania's forests, it has patently failed to do so. Mr Field, in his letter to the then Prime Minister Hawke on 10 November 1989, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Unless we are able to secure your agreement for funding as requested, the conflict about Tasmania's forests will resume and will inevitably involve the Federal Government.

Federal funds were granted to resolve the problem, yet state forests still in conflict include the Great Western Tiers, the Southern Forests, Lorinna, the Gog Range, Ellendale, the Tarkine and now Reedy Marsh. Conflict over dry forests in Tasmania will undoubtedly grow. It is apparent, therefore, that the so-called forests and forest industry strategy has neither solved nor diminished the conflict over those forests. It is not even an agreed strategy. Its credibility is sadly in question.

PARA.TAB: The Forestry Commission of Tasmania asserts that this is a sawlog driven strategy. I would suggest that is a lot of rubbish because the figures obtained from the Forestry Commission show that at Parrot Creek coupe, for instance, only approximately six per cent taken were potential sawlogs. Ninety-four percent was designated waste, conveniently diverted to chipping and pulp. In some forest coupes the waste which goes overseas, mainly to Japan, as woodchips may be as high as 98 per cent. So much for a strategy which is sawlog driven. This is all the more offensive when it is remembered that in a poll taken in December 1991 in Tasmania 76 per cent of Tasmanians rejected export woodchipping.

By the Forestry Commission's own estimates, in the next five to eight years as little as 5,000 tonnes of sawlogs will come from the Reedy Marsh forest, but in the process some 75,000 tonnes of waste logs will be produced by clear-filling for export woodchips. That is a wastage rate of 95 per cent. I doubt that any other industry would dare attempt to justify such wastage. The assertion that this is a sawlog driven industry is blatantly and intentionally dishonest.

Clearly, the public is unaware of the extent of this and is deceived by this gross misrepresentation. Until now the public has accepted an industrial practice that is either extraordinarily wasteful on the one hand or extraordinarily dishonest on the other, and in doing so ravages vulnerable forests.

In short, the present policies of the state government, its Forestry Commission and present practices of the industry are openly dishonest. They are also ecologically irresponsible and they clearly reflect the failure of the forests and forest industry strategy. Further roading and logging of natural forests will merely entrench this failure.

It was because of all this that the Tasmanian Forestry Commission's application for membership of the International Union for the Conservation of Nature, comprising 100 governments and 600 non-government organisations, was rejected in 1990 by its central assembly in Perth. I doubt that anyone would have been surprised by that.

Officers of the Forestry Commission have advised the Reedy Marsh forest conservation group that many of those dry forests being considered here regenerate very slowly, well in excess of the commission's stated 80 to 85 years sustainable rotation for sawlog. It can be asserted that these forests are clearly conditional by the commission's own definition, as is seen in the Forestry Commission Technical Bulletin No. 3 of 1991 where these are described as low land dry eucalypt forests.

Conditional forests are those whose regeneration is conditional upon a series of determining factors being favourable; for example, absence of prolonged drought, presence of acceptable soil types, absence of serious fire damage, et cetera. When the probability of those occurring simultaneously is low, the forests are described as conditional. The commission's policy is that such forests should not be logged. Arguably, most of the dry forests are conditional. The Reedy Marsh fo-

SPEECH.PARA: rest most certainly is, as is evidenced by the extraordinarily slow regeneration of portions of the forest that had been clear-felled 15 years ago.

PARA.TAB: The Forestry Commission itself estimates that these areas may take up to 150 years or six generations to regenerate. Although there are at present four small recommended areas for protection, in the Reedy Marsh forest extensive areas between these areas of protection are being clear-felled. As much as 75 per cent of the forests could ultimately be logged in a checkerboard fashion.

In short, in conditional forests the environmental cost of logging is high and economic return poor. The recovery time will be substantially longer, at least 50 per cent, than estimates previously quoted by the commission and deceptively promoted under the forests and forest industry strategy as sustainable strategy. Logging dry forests is clearly not economically sustainable and to do so is grossly irresponsible and negligent. I intend to bring to the Senate further information about such practices.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 15 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the concern of Wallangarra residents that the Commonwealth Effluent Disposal (CED) scheme installed at the end of Merinda Street in Wallangarra could be an environmental risk, and the subsequent press release issued by the Stanthorpe Shire Council on 30 November 1993 which states that `as soon as investigations are finalised application will be made to the Department of Environment and Heritage for issue of a licence to discharge to the creek', and given that the creek mentioned in the council press release is Accommodation Creek and this is part of the Murray-Darling River system:
(1) Will an investigation be held as to whether the effluent discharge will flow into the Murray-Darling River system.
(2) Will the level of blue green algae and other contaminants in the CED ponds in Wallangarra be investigated.
(3) Will steps be taken to inform the residents of Wallangarra of the results of any tests done.
(4) Will action be taken to mitigate any harmful results caused by an overflow of the Wallangarra CED ponds into Accommodation Creek.

TALK.START.PARA: —The following answer is provided to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1), (2), (3) and (4) The Commonwealth has no financial interest in any effluent disposal schemes in Wallangarra. Responsibility for the common effluent drainage scheme referred to is entirely a local and State government matter. In particular the Stanthorpe Shire Council is responsible for water and wastewater operations and the Queensland Department of Environment and Heritage for effluent approval. No Commonwealth action is proposed on the matter.

I am advised by Queensland officials that the potential effluent contributions from the common effluent drainage scheme for Wallangarra, a town of less than 200 population, are minor and would only occur in conjunction with occasional peak rainfall events.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 20 December 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What additional costs and staffing resources in the 1992-93, 1993-94 and the 1994-95 financial year are expected to be required to process all applications for permanent residence which will occur as a result of the Government's 1 November 1993 decision, given that character and health checks will need to be undertaken before permanent residence is granted.

(2) Will people who arrived as dependent spouses prior to the regulations being tightened in 1992 concerning class 437 visas, and who have since separated or divorced, be eligible to apply for permanent residency under the Government's 1 November 1993 decision.

(3) Will people who have applied for refugee status, but have been rejected and are currently seeking a review of the decision with the Refugee Review Tribunal or through the judicial system, be eligible to apply for the special assistance category announced on 1 November 1993.

(4) Will foreign nationals whose applications for refugee status were refused, and who in some cases may have left Australia, be eligible to apply under the special assistance category announced on 1 November 1993.

(5) Is the Government aware of any allegations that some People's Republic of China (PRC) nationals in Australia have maintained close links with the Chinese Communist Party, are associated with illegal activities, participated in migration scams and provided fraudulent documentation on migration applications; if so, please provide details, including details of any action the Government has taken to follow up these matters, and if they are found to have substance, will they be taken into account in determining whether or not to grant permanent residence.

(6) Given that many of the PRC nationals eligible to apply for permanent residency under the Government's 1 November 1993 decision arrived here under the English language intensive courses for overseas students which prior to December 1990 required no character checks prior to the issuing of visas, will the same individual character checking procedures be undertaken in respect of all people who qualify to apply under the Government's 1 November 1993 announcement as currently occur with other permanent residence applications; if so, what implications will this have in respect of setting precedents for character check requirements for other permanent resident applicants; if not, why not.

(7) With reference to the profile provided by the department which said that of the 19,540 PRC nationals in Australia on 20 June 1989, 7,250 were in Australia illegally on expired permits: (a) will those people who were in Australia illegally on 20 June 1989 be granted access to permanent residency, and (b) will character check assessments take account of any violations of Australia's visa laws.

(8) With reference to the profile provided by the department which shows that, on 1 June 1993, 4,040 of those PRC nationals who arrived in Australia after 20 June 1989 were here illegally: (a) will these people be eligible to apply for permanent residence under the Government's 1 November 1993 announcement; and (b) will character check assessments take account of any violation of Australia's visa laws.

(9) Of those PRC nationals who applied for refugee status but whose applications have been rejected, has the Government received any indication that PRC nationals would be subject to persecution or other penalties by the Chinese Government.
(10) What does the Government mean by the definition `vocational English' with regard to the special assistance category announced on 1 November 1993.

(11) Will the Government be using the Australian Assessment of Communicative English Skills test which it has developed for assessing English language abilities for applications made under the special assistance category announced on 1 November 1993; if not, why not.

(12) Has the Government made any estimates of the costs of English language training for those who are accepted as permanent residents as a result of the Government's 1 November 1993 decision; if so, what are the expected costs, and how many people will be likely to require English training; if not, why not.

(13) With reference to visitor visa applications received since 20 June 1989 from: (a) Beijing; and (b) Shanghai: (i) how many visitor visa applications were made, and how many were approved, (ii) has there been any investigation or assessment made of visitor visa applications from either Beijing or Shanghai since 1989; if so, with what result and how many, if any, visitor visa applications have been found to be presented in a "mass produced", or very similar, format, (iii) how many supporting documents has the department found to be signed or co-signed by a single notary, or small number of notaries, (iv) has the department found that a small number of migration agents have assisted a large number or percentage of the applications for visitor or other visas; if so, please provide details by visa class, (v) how many applications were from people who on investigation were found already to be in Australia; and (vi) how many sponsors sponsored more than three applications for visitor or other visas.
(14) How many applications received since 20 June 1989 have originated in the Fujian Province in the PRC.
(15) Is the department aware of any organisations or individuals providing or selling false documentation in Australia for people to submit with migration applications; if so, please provide details.
(16) Is the Government aware of any false documentation that has been provided by migration agents in Australia; if so, has it taken any action to de-register them, please provide details.
(17) What are the names of the top ten migration agents known to be helping PRC nationals with Determination of Refugee Status applications, and how many applications have they each assisted.

(18) Will members of particular Chinese student or other organisations be given preferential processing of applications made in respect of the Government's 1 November 1993 decision; if so, which organisations, and how many members do they have.
(19) Has the department found any similarity of claims and similar or identical supporting documents in applications prepared by particular migration agents; if so, please provide details.

(20) Is the department aware of any PRC nationals having overstayed their student visas without re-enrolling or attending the course which was the reason for their being granted a visa; if so, please provide details.

(21) Is the department aware of any false Australian language course attendance certificates that have been provided with immigration applications, and what actions and checking procedures has it taken to ensure students are bona-fide.

(22) Of the spouses who were sponsored by holders of the special class 437 permit, how many and what percentage were found to have entered Australia on the basis of false documentation provided in applications, and what action has been taken in relation to these cases.
(23) How many of the people who arrived here as spouses have made applications to sponsor other relatives to enter Australia, please provide details.
(24) Are there any cases pending against suspect solicitors, notaries and Justices of the Peace involved in alleged illegal immigration schemes; if so, how many.
(25) Have any PRC nationals who arrived in Australia on student visas registered as migration agents; if so, please provide details.
(26) Is the department aware of any language schools being suspected of, or found to be, linked to illegal immigration schemes or alleged criminal activities; if so, please provide details.
(27) Could the answer to this question be provided within 30 days of 20 December 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) It is expected that the processing of applications affected by the Government's 1 November 1993 decision will be funded principally by the application fees received. The staff resources and costs will be dependent upon the number of applications received. Any additional costs to the organisation (eg the processing of fee-exempt applications in cases of hardship) will be borne by the Department out of its existing funding base. The organisations providing penal and health clearances will fund their activities from the fees charged by that organisation.
(2) Yes
(3) Yes

(4) Foreign Nationals whose applications for refugee status were refused and were in Australia on 1 November 1993, or who had a valid re-entry visa, will be eligible to apply under the special entry permit category announced on 1 November 1993.
(5) Advice on allegations that some PRC nationals have maintained close links with the Chinese Communist Party or are associated with illegal activities is properly the province of other agencies.

I can confirm that some PRC nationals have been involved in scams involving the use of fraudulent documentation to support applications for visas to Australia. In 1991 and 1992 fraudulent documentation was a recurring feature of the visitor caseload in the PRC and the student dependent caseload which was handled in Beijing. Officers at the overseas posts became familiar with the characteristics of falsified applications and were able to readily recognise and reject such applications. Following the exposure of these scams, procedures were modified where necessary and relevant areas of the Department and other relevant agencies were alerted. One of the individuals centrally involved in these and other forms of immigration malpractice was successfully prosecuted.

Where a person has been involved in criminal or other conduct prejudicial to the public interest, and those activities are found to have substance, each case will be considered on its merits under the Public Interest criteria of the Regulations and on the basis of the advice of any other agency. Where a person has been subject to a criminal conviction due to immigration malpractice, the conviction will be taken into account in considering his or her application.

(6) Character checks will not be undertaken in the home countries. This is consistent with the practice for persons applying for refugee status and the subsequent application for residence. The special provisions apply to those who fear return to their home countries. It would be inconsistent to seek character clearances from the authorities from which they have fled or to which they fear return. There is no precedence with these procedures for other residence categories. Usual onshore clearances will be undertaken.
(7)(a) Yes
(7)(b) No. But where a person has been subject to criminal convictions due to immigration malpractice, the conviction will be taken into account.
(8)(a) If they entered legally before 1 November 1993 on a visa issued prior to 12 March 1992 and applied for refugee status prior to 1 November 1993, yes.
(8)(b) No. But where a person has been subject to criminal convictions due to immigration malpractice, the conviction will be taken into account.

(9) The Australian Embassy in Beijing and Australian Consulate in Shanghai monitor, as resources permit, the situation of persons previously applicants for refugee status who have returned to the Peoples Republic of China. Where specific allegations of mistreatment have been made inquiries are made. To date no information has been received to indicate that returnees who, after being determined not to be a refugee under the DORS process in Australia, have returned to China have suffered persecution in terms of the 1951 United Nations Convention and the 1967 Protocol relating to the Status of Refugees. Information received from other reliable sources concurs with this view.

(10) A definition is provided in Regulations to reflect the November 1 decision. The applicant is to have the ability to communicate in English in a mix of social and work situations. The ways in which this can be demonstrated are contained in the Regulations. The definition is not to be confused with that currently being used for off-shore English language testing.

There will be a number of options whereby applicants can demonstrate that they have the standard of English required to meet the criteria under the 1 November 1993 provisions. One option will be to undertake the Special Entry Permit Category English Test which is currently being developed by the same organisation responsible for the development of the Australian Assessment of Communicative English Skills test (ACCESS). This test is being specifically designed to cater to the level of proficiency required for this particular group and assessment time-frames allowed for implementing the decision. The ACCESS test does not meet this specific need and as such requires some modification, hence the need to identify it as a separate test and avoid confusion with off-shore `vocational' testing. It is expected that the newly designed test will be compatible with the ACCESS test.

The pre 20 June 1989 group have already been in Australia for four years, and have undertaken study in Australian institutions. The spouses and dependents of this group have had access to English language training in the schools or through the Adult Migrant English Program (AMEP).

Applicants on the basis of applying for Refugee Status or the persons from the former Republic of Yugoslavia and Sri Lanka who applied for the concessional humanitarian entry permits prior to 1 November 1993 are required to demonstrate that they have a level of English sufficient for the mix of social and work situations. They will not require English language training. Dependents of this group may require English language training.

(13)(ii) As indicated at Question 5, an analysis of a large sample of suspect visitor visa applications was undertaken in 1991-1992. Some 400 suspect applications were examined.

There is no exact figure of how many suspect applications were received. As an indication, however, in early 1992 the Principal Migration Officer in Shanghai reported that since September 1991, 60% of all visitor applications had characteristics that suggested they were suspect.
(13)(iii) All of the documentation lodged with suspect applications was notarised. The certifications of 28 notaries public appeared with varying degrees of frequency in those applications.

(13)(iv) The names of migration agents or agencies rarely appeared in the documentation which accompanied the suspect visitor applications. Names of agencies were more often openly associated with student dependant applications. Both scams pre-dated the commencement of the Migration Agents Registration legislation.

(13)(v) Under the visitor visa scam many of the spouses of the visitor visa applicants were said to be in China but on investigation were shown to be in Australia. This was a common feature of the scam and may have been a reason for its inception, although the formula was later used to try to achieve the entry of all types of individuals, not necessarily the spouses of PRC nationals temporarily or illegally in Australia.
(13)(vi) Over the period of investigation of the visitor visa scam around 200 different names appeared as sponsors. Of those, 28 names appeared more than three times.
(14) Detailed statistics of the province that applicants reside in are not available.
(15) The Department is aware that packages of bogus information and documents were furnished to applicants to form part of an application to the Department.
(16) My Department is not aware of any registered migration agents providing false documentation.

(17) Statistics relating to numbers of applicants assisted by individual migration agents are not kept. Applicants are not requested to provide the name of the agent, if any, that may have assisted them.

(19) There have been some cases where similar claims or documents have been submitted by individual applicants but the incidence of such practice appears to be decreasing. Applicants whose claims or documents are similar to those of other asylum seekers are asked at interview to explain the similarity.

(20) The Department is aware of PRC nationals overstaying their student visas and have not re-enrolled. Precise details are not readily available. Some may not yet have finalised their plans for the coming year and others are applicants for Refugee status.

(21) Allegations have been made. Many of these are the subject of ongoing investigation. It would be inappropriate to provide details at this time. As part of the criteria for students to extend their stay in Australia, they are required to satisfy officers of the Department that they are genuine students.
(22) Where fraudulent documentation was found in support of an application for a class 783 visa, the application was refused.
(23) Spouses of 437 holders are not eligible to sponsor other relatives to Australia, with the exception of dependent children.

(24) There are 12 cases under investigation involving Justices of the Peace and notaries, 2 involving solicitors, and 7 involving Migration agents. Briefs awaiting consideration by the Director for Public Prosecution for possible litigation involve 4 Justices of the Peace and notaries, 2 Solicitors, and 16 Migration Agents.

(25) To be registered as a migration agent an applicant must, inter alia, be an Australian citizen or permanent resident. The registration process does not require an applicant to inform my Department of their immigration status prior to acquisition of citizenship or permanent residence.

(26) Some employees of English language schools are under investigation for possible offences against Commonwealth legislation. As investigations are incomplete and litigation may result, it is not possible to provide further information at this time.
